Campbell, who was released on bail, claims the harassment involved tweets that were not threatening and accused the media of encouraging speculation. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegations of online harassment.

Peta is asking for the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness to be replaced with a fish mascot with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" because they believe the Jolly Fisherman represents animal cruelty. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, said he doesn't think there will be much support for the mascot to be replaced and that the Jolly Fisherman is loved by many.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, scoring six tries to two. Scotland dominated possession and territory in the first half, scoring three quick tries and holding Georgia to only one try. Georgia scored their second try in the second half, but Scotland responded with another try to secure the victory. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance, highlighting their ability to hold the ball and counter-attack effectively.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-24, moving them into 7th place in the league. Widnes had a 26-point lead before Castleford scored three tries in four minutes, making the final score closer.  Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti citizen detained at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, was released after a US review panel determined he was not a threat to the US. He will now spend at least a year at a rehabilitation center in Kuwait. Mr. Odah was the first inmate released since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. His release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay down to 148.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The day is marked by services in London, including a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade to the Cenotaph, and a service at Westminster Abbey. The services honor the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand soldiers in all wars. The first Anzac Day commemoration in London was in 1916 when King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey.

St Mirren's new player, 30-year-old striker,  Jonathan Clarkson, is ready to make his debut against Alloa on Saturday. Clarkson has played for several teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. He scored nine goals last season at Dundee and is looking forward to helping St Mirren move up the Championship table.

The Bernard Matthews turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan.  Unite, the union representing the workers, was assured that the current pension arrangements would remain in place under the new ownership.  Boparan plans to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability by investing in the business, cutting costs, and utilizing the company's spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The new chain ferry in Cowes has had a difficult start, experiencing breakdowns, groundings, and training issues. The council has ordered an audit of the project and is offering free crossings until July 2nd to gather feedback. Local businesses are suffering from the loss of trade and are seeking compensation. The council is considering compensation and has authorized ramp extensions to address vehicle damage.

The House of Lords European Union Committee released a report that examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry after Brexit. The report warns that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a deal. The report also states that the UK fishing industry is small, accounting for only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people. The report suggests that the UK should retain many elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and continue to base total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. The report also notes that the UK will continue to be under international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. Despite the report's warnings, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about Brexit, believing it will bring more opportunities than threats.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, was found guilty of possessing child pornography and was removed from the General Teaching Council Scotland register. He was sentenced to a community payback order and required to participate in a sex offender program. The panel found that Geaney's actions were "fundamentally incompatible" with being a teacher and that there was a "strong likelihood of the offending behaviour recurring." He was prohibited from re-registering for two years.

On March 2nd, a fire at a waste facility in Duncan Street caused travel delays and service disruptions. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the facility's waste acceptance permit after determining that the site operators, Asset and Land Group, were "broadly compliant" with fire safety regulations. The EA revoked the facility's environmental permit, effective August 7th, after concerns were raised by the Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) about the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transportation, and the environment. The cause of the fire is still under investigation.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile, but Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad claims that two shipments of weapons were attacked by terrorists on their way to the port of Latakia. He also denies the use of barrel bombs by the Syrian government, despite reports of civilian casualties in Aleppo. The Syrian government also denies that rebels have seized most of Aleppo's central prison, claiming that soldiers and security forces thwarted an attack by terrorist groups. The US is concerned that the UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons is falling behind schedule, while Russia has set a new deadline of March 1st for the transfer of weapons to the coast.

England won the second Test match against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. Joe Root was named man of the match after scoring 254 runs in the first innings and 71 runs in the second. England's bowling attack was also strong, bowling Pakistan out for 234 in the second innings. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, admitted that his team was short of confidence and that their shot selection cost them the match.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will be gathering information from pensioners, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations for improving care. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira hopes to highlight good care while also addressing the impact of poor care. The review has been met with support from Care Forum Wales, but the group expressed disappointment that no care provider experts were included on the advisory panel.

Paul Sheerin, former midfielder for Aberdeen, has been appointed as the new manager of the team. Sheerin previously managed Arbroath, leading them to their first national trophy in 2011. He replaces Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, stated that the decision was made after a thorough process and that Arbroath's chairman was understanding of Sheerin's desire to return to Aberdeen.

Swansea City is looking for a new manager after firing Bob Bradley. Curtis and Paul Williams will manage the team for the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club wants to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis, a former player, believes the club has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, and that the team has not been able to adequately replace the players they have lost. He believes the current squad is good enough to stay up, and reminds new players of the club's history and how important it is to stay in the Premier League.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his groundbreaking work in human genomics and synthetic biology. He is a controversial figure, often criticized for his competitive approach and disregard for scientific conventions. Despite this, his work has significantly accelerated the field of genomics. He is credited with creating the first complete genome of a free-living organism and leading the effort to create the world's first synthetic life form, Synthia. Dr. Venter's work has been driven by a sense of urgency, stemming from his experiences as a medic in the Vietnam War. He has also been a pioneer in oceanographic research, collecting and sequencing genomes from marine microbes. His work has the potential to revolutionize industries and address environmental challenges.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short compared to other European countries. The report calls for a significant increase in apprenticeships, with a focus on level three qualifications, which are equivalent to A-levels. The report criticizes the current system, which has too many low-level apprenticeships and a shortage of places for young people. The Department for Education says they are reforming apprenticeships to improve standards and make them more relevant to employers. The Association of Colleges agrees that more apprenticeships are needed but warns that creating 300,000 new apprenticeships would be a challenge. They also argue that some level two apprenticeships, such as those in construction, are well-respected and should be preserved.

British Paralympian Sarah Storey won the women's time trial at the Para-cycling Road World Championships in Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of the second-place finisher. This victory brings Storey closer to her 17th world title, which she can achieve in Saturday's road race. Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, has won 22 medals across six Paralympics in both cycling and swimming. She is aiming for further Paralympic success at the 2016 Rio Games.

Hereford United was expelled from the Football Conference on June 10th, 2014, due to their inability to pay their debts. The club had been given multiple extensions to pay their creditors, but ultimately failed to meet the deadline. The club's financial struggles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, with falling attendance exacerbating the situation. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust had offered to buy the club for £1 and clear their debts, but their offer was not accepted. The club was taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar in June 2014, but he was unable to save the club from expulsion.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after 61 caps for England. He was a member of two World Cup and two European Championship squads, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps and scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in 2014.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. Hogwood was a leading figure in the early-music movement, working with numerous orchestras worldwide. He founded the AAM in 1973 and led it for 30 years, during which time the academy produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a respected academic, holding positions at Harvard University, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell University. He was praised by colleagues for his generosity, his dedication to historically informed music, and his influence on the development of musicians worldwide.

A boy from Northern Ireland with special needs was removed from mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping. His family requested a place at a special school, but all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full. The family was told that an extra classroom assistant has been employed at a local special school and the boy may be able to start there soon. The boy's mother is concerned that this situation will happen to other families because the special needs school system is packed to capacity. The Education Authority is reviewing the profile of need for special school places in Northern Ireland and is working to ensure that places are available close to where the children reside.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, which would make Rodney Parade a rugby venue. Newport County, who have a lease on the ground until 2023, are expecting their contract to be honored. The WRU's takeover will be voted on May 9th. The WRU has stated their intention to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of relegation in League Two and could secure survival this weekend. Relegation to the National League would be a "massive" blow to the club and the city of Newport.

The passage tells the story of a Sierra Leonean man who was kidnapped by rebels as a teenager and forced to fight in the civil war. He escaped and later found a home and purpose through a project called Lifeline Nehemiah. He then became involved in fighting the Ebola outbreak in Sierra Leone, educating people about the virus and providing support to those affected. He believes that investing in young people is key to building a better future.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised enough money to prevent the auction of 80,000 pieces of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum. The Art Fund, which led the campaign, will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, before it is loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The collection was at risk of being sold and scattered around the globe if the money had not been raised.

Glenn Tamplin, a multi-millionaire, recently purchased Billericay, a club in the Isthmian League Premier Division. Tamplin has stated he is willing to invest £10,000 a week in the club.  The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky and is in talks with former I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here contestant, Mark Wright, about a potential 20% ownership stake in the club.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso passed to Jamille Matt, who scored. Colchester tied the game after 17 minutes when Kurtis Guthrie scored after a goalmouth scramble. Colchester had a chance to take the lead before halftime, but Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made a save. Blackpool had a chance to win the game 15 minutes before the end, but Tom Aldred missed a header. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was given a red card for a bad tackle.

The Fawley power station, which closed in 2013 after 40 years of operation, is being redeveloped into a "merchant city" with a marina, housing, and restaurants. The developers plan to keep the 198-meter-high chimney, which is the tallest structure south of London's Shard, as the centerpiece of the £1 billion development. The project, which could begin in 2018, will also include fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth.

The Great Britain cycling team competed in the Hong Kong World Championships.  Ethan Latham won bronze in the men's omnium, while the men's team pursuit team lost to Italy for the bronze medal.  The women's team pursuit team finished fifth in the heats and did not qualify for the bronze medal ride.  Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint.  The women's team pursuit team was comprised of Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, Ellie Dickinson, and Elinor Barker.  The team was positive about their performance, despite not medaling, as they are a young team with a lot of potential.

Ross Kemp, who played Grant Mitchell on the soap opera EastEnders, will return to the show for a brief period to film the final episodes of Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Peggy Mitchell, who returned to the show in 2015, will be killed off in the spring. Kemp will return to the show to reunite the Mitchell family for the last time before Peggy's death.

Liverpool defeated Tottenham Hotspur 2-1 at Anfield, with Sadio Mane scoring two goals within two minutes and 18 seconds. Tottenham manager Mauricio Pochettino expressed his disappointment with his team's performance, stating that they were not ready to fight for the Premier League title. He also expressed concern about Chelsea's potential 12-point lead if they win against Burnley. Tottenham has struggled on the road, winning only twice since September 24th, and has only won once in their last 17 away matches against top-six teams. Former Liverpool and Tottenham midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Tottenham's performance, highlighting their lack of pace and different mindset when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This is the PDP's first loss in a presidential election since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's victory was particularly strong in the north, including key states like Katsina and Kaduna. The PDP managed to hold onto Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub, and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's success has relegated the PDP to a regional party, while the APC has gained control of Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge to President-elect Muhammadu Buhari as militant groups could disrupt oil production. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP will need to rebuild itself under a new leader after 16 years in power.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information from signs and posters on the festival grounds. The app will provide videos, band interviews, and other content, allowing people around the world to experience the festival virtually.

The Department for Education will terminate the funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary schools, both rated inadequate by Ofsted. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, were warned they could lose funding unless concerns were addressed. The Department for Education has concerns about the way Park View School is run, including its failure to promote the spiritual, moral, social and cultural development of pupils. The Department for Education also has concerns about Oldknow Academy's failure to meet the requirements set out in its funding agreement, including the less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, the segregation of boys and girls, and the lack of a broad and balanced curriculum. Ofsted found that a culture of fear and intimidation has taken grip in Birmingham schools, and that there has been an organized campaign to target certain schools in order to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology.

Honey Rose, an eye specialist, is on trial for gross negligence manslaughter after the death of Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie. The prosecution alleges that Rose failed to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during a routine eye exam, which led to a build-up of fluid in his brain and ultimately his death. The prosecution argues that Rose's conduct was "so bad" and "fell so far below the standards to be expected of a competent optometrist" that it was criminal.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into having sex with a man he found on an adult website and filming the encounter. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the woman's sister on Christmas Day. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and the case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers.

Ireland lost to Afghanistan in the first T20 match by six runs. Ireland scored 165-5 with Stuart Thompson scoring 56 runs. Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs to spare, with Samiullah Shenwari scoring 56 runs and Mohammad Shahzad scoring 47 runs. The two teams will play again on Friday.

Barcelona paid £48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost of the player, including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and taxes, is £106.8 million. The club is being investigated for possible tax fraud related to the transfer, but they insist they have not committed any wrongdoing. Barcelona has made a complimentary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 to cover any potential discrepancies in the original tax payment.

British police officers traveled to Thailand to review the investigation into the murders of Hannah Witheridge and David Miller. The officers will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. The UK police team expressed concerns about the verification of DNA samples of the suspects and allegations of their mistreatment.

Scotland's women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for the 2017 European Championship. They have won all five of their qualifying matches and are in a strong position to reach the finals in the Netherlands. The team is led by Bayern Munich forward, Jane Evans, who believes that the experience of playing in top leagues abroad has helped the team improve. Scotland is set to face Iceland in a crucial match on Friday, with the winner likely to top the group.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from accessing iCloud data. This measure, called two-factor authentication, requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password. While this measure is optional, security experts recommend making it the default option. The new security measure prevents software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker from accessing iCloud data. However, concerns remain about the security of the recovery key, which can be lost or stolen. Experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default setting for all companies, including Apple, Microsoft, and Google.

The UKIP, Tories, Lib Dems, Labour, Green Party, and SNP spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning for the 2014 European election. The UKIP spent the most at £2,956,737, followed by the Tories at £2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent £1,580,575, Labour spent £1,027,339, the Green Party spent £534,249, and the SNP spent £267,372. All parties except Labour spent more than they did in the 2009 European election.

Barrow centre-back Anderson, 27, has left the club to join a rival National League team. Striker Keating, 21, has joined Barrow from Finn Harps, subject to international clearance.  Barrow manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as hungry to prove himself. Barrow is currently four points above the relegation zone.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," which is a rare occurrence in horses without underlying health issues. While Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, he had never collapsed before and showed no signs of it on Saturday. Despite the rarity of this incident, the BHA is determined to understand the cause and find ways to prevent it.

Several MSPs, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, are stepping down from the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond, in his farewell speech, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that the parliament should assume greater responsibility for governing the country. He welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but insisted it did not fulfill the pledges made by unionist politicians during the referendum campaign. McNeil, in his final speech, warned that Holyrood has things to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system, and emphasized the importance of accountability and scrutiny.

The live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast will star Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, and Luke Evans as Gaston. The film will also feature Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts. The film is directed by Bill Condon and will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decision on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects in the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, which killed 96 football fans. The decision will be revealed at a meeting with victims' relatives. The CPS will decide whether to bring charges against 15 suspects related to the causes of the disaster and 8 suspects related to the police conduct in the aftermath.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over the wall, including four times in two weeks according to a nearby resident.  A former inmate claims the prison is notorious for contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, and that drones are used to smuggle goods into the prison. The Ministry of Justice denies the use of drones at Chelmsford Prison, but acknowledges the problem of contraband and states that staff are working hard to stop it.  The Ministry of Justice also states that new laws have been introduced that could result in a two-year prison sentence for those caught smuggling contraband into prisons.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving after he hit Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, with his car. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions, stating he understands Blackburn was a beloved lollipop lady and that he has turned her world upside down.

Scottish runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new personal best in the 5,000m. She is considering competing in the World Indoor Championships in March and is looking forward to future Olympic opportunities.

Trevor Deely, 22, disappeared in December 2000 after attending a Christmas party.  Police are searching a three-acre wooded area near the River Liffey in Dublin, which is expected to take several weeks.  The search comes after a review of Deely's disappearance, which included enhancing CCTV footage from the night he went missing.  The footage shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland.  Police believe this man is the same one who followed Deely shortly after.  Police have renewed their appeal for the man in the CCTV footage to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a thrilling match at Wimbledon. Del Potro, who has been sidelined for two years due to injuries, is now in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. Nick Kyrgios, who is also in the same half of the draw as Murray, defeated Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. Feliciano Lopez will play Kyrgios in the third round. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won their matches.

Tunisia and Morocco both faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) during the 2015 Nations Cup. Morocco was banned from participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after refusing to host the 2015 Nations Cup due to fears of the Ebola virus. However, the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and reduced the fine imposed on Morocco's FA. Both countries have since apologized to CAF and are now eligible to compete in the 2017 Nations Cup.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, is currently experiencing a period of decline. The team has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, but their recent performance has been disappointing. The slump began in 2013 with issues in chassis design, and despite improvements in the car, the Honda power unit has been a major obstacle. McLaren's greatest successes came during their partnership with Honda in the 1980s and 1990s, but their recent struggles have led to questions about the team's future. Ron Dennis, the team's CEO, believes that McLaren will return to success and break Mercedes' dominance in Formula 1. He points to the team's progress with the car and the potential of the Honda engine. However, the team's current situation is precarious, and their success hinges on their ability to overcome their challenges.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after being found to have served alcohol past licensing hours. The bar was found to have served alcohol as late as 04:49 BST on October 6, 2014, and the judge stated that the bar had "an appalling record" and had not been run properly. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was fined £3,000 and James Thomas was fined £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and hitting eight three-pointers to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. The Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol leading the Bulls with 16 points and 15 rebounds.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen arrived at Melwood. Van Velzen, a free-kick specialist, fooled the players into thinking he was a competition winner who had won the opportunity to meet the Anfield stars and receive a dead-ball masterclass. Van Velzen, however, impressed the players with his free-kick skills, even scoring a goal past the stand-in keeper. Van Velzen, who has become a YouTube sensation by uploading videos of his free-kick exploits, enjoyed the experience and was happy to see the players' reactions to his skills.

A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene mutations found that women who had their ovaries removed (oophorectomy) after diagnosis had a 62% lower risk of dying from breast cancer. This effect was only seen in women with the BRCA1 mutation. The study also found that oophorectomy was associated with a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The authors of the study recommend that oophorectomy be considered as part of the treatment discussion for women with BRCA mutations and early-stage breast cancer.

On Easter Sunday, a married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina. The train, the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City when the accident occurred. None of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, but a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for almost three hours before continuing on its route. The Lowes were pronounced dead at the scene. A man who met the couple while collecting scrap metal said they may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, worked as an informant for the DEA for 27 years in exchange for US citizenship. Toro, who fled Colombia after a confrontation with his boss, provided information that led to the prosecution of several cartel members, including Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite his service, Toro was not granted citizenship and is now facing deportation. He fears for his life if he is returned to Colombia, as he believes he will be killed. The DEA has refused to help Toro with his citizenship, and he is currently living in the US illegally.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is investigating Vox Populi Registry Ltd., a Canadian company that has registered domain names ending in ".sucks" for major brands and celebrities. ICANN is looking into whether Vox Populi's actions are illegal after receiving complaints from industry groups and companies. Vox Populi has been selling these domain names for around $2,499 a year, and celebrities like Kevin Spacey have reportedly paid to have their names removed. ICANN is considering declaring Vox Populi in breach of its contract and seeking to change the registry's behavior.

A baby boy's body was found in a pond in 1988. After 27 years, police exhumed the body and used DNA to identify the mother. The mother admitted to concealing her pregnancy and giving birth to a stillborn baby. She placed the baby in the pond. The mother was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped. The police are now investigating whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby was reburied with a headstone and named Peter after the church.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was found liable for the severe brain injuries sustained by his passenger, Kristopher Hicks, after Hicks jumped out of the moving car. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was going to skip out on the fare and decided to drive him back to the taxi rank as a punishment. Hicks, feeling unlawfully imprisoned, jumped out of the car while it was traveling at over 20 mph, resulting in devastating brain injuries. The judge ruled that Young's actions constituted unlawful imprisonment and awarded Hicks damages, though the exact amount is still to be determined.

On Wednesday night, tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri. In Kansas, spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, which moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing a threat to other communities. Other tornadoes were reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. In Missouri, a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and downed trees. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is looking to extend his winning streak to four by defeating Lyoto Machida in their middleweight clash. Rockhold plans to be aggressive and dominate Machida, who he believes is vulnerable on the ground. Machida, however, is confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. He believes his style and technique will be enough to defeat Rockhold, and he is well-prepared for the fight.

A light general aviation aircraft landed at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without its landing gear deployed. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, realized his mistake and managed to take off again, despite the plane's propellers hitting the runway. The plane flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is most commonly caused by human error or mechanical failure.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed his disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season, but has vowed to support the midfielder until the end of the season.  Pellegrini has also stated that Toure does not need a break, despite criticism of his performance.  Manchester City will listen to offers for Toure in the summer, as they look to overhaul their aging squad.  Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players who have moved to Manchester City, such as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair, who did not play much.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive dubbed the "Godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK after his sentence was dropped. Rancadore was convicted in absentia in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra and sentenced to seven years in prison. In February 2014, he lost his battle against extradition and was ordered to return to Italy to serve his sentence. However, it was revealed that his sentence expired in October 2014, and his European arrest warrant will be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains intact, Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished after a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still be heard by the Italian Supreme Court.

Mr. Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three co-favorites in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday. This will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race. The race will include six other runners, including Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. McCoy's book of rides for his final day as a professional jockey will be finalized on Friday morning.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and murdered in 1975 by Jerome Sydney Barrett.  After 40 years, Ritter finally viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body.  She had previously declined to see the photos, but after viewing them, she expressed a desire for revenge.  Barrett was found guilty of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy is aiming to win the Masters this year to complete his career grand slam. He believes that winning all four major titles is a significant achievement, as it requires success on different courses and under different conditions. McIlroy is confident in his ability to win at Augusta, despite his past struggles there, including a final-round collapse in 2011. He views that experience as a valuable learning opportunity, which helped him to win his first major title at the US Open two months later. McIlroy is looking forward to using the golf course as a sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding the Masters.

This week's trending stories included a photo of four rainbows in the sky after heavy rain in New York, a crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes in rural China, Robert Downey Jr.'s agitation at a UK interviewer's questions about his private life, a new trend of lip plumping by sucking on a jar to look like Kylie Jenner, a 102-year-old woman's time travel experience with filmmakers, a prom-posal referencing bombs that was deemed inappropriate by school administrators, Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer, a pregnant woman's "Fresh Prince of Bel-Air" themed announcement, and a military dad photobombing his son's photo.

In England, 272 children were hospitalized in the past year due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS), a disability caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. This number is likely much lower than the actual number of children affected, as research suggests that at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure. FAS can cause lifelong disabilities, such as difficulty learning, holding a pencil, and paying attention. Other medical issues associated with alcohol consumption during pregnancy include problems with the liver, kidneys, heart, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. The government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol, but some experts believe that women should not drink at all during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew Mckerry, known as "Boomerang Boy" for his repeated return to crime after being released from prison, attempted to rob a post office in County Durham. He was tackled by the store owner, Sab Dhillon, and hit with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam. Mckerry was arrested and sentenced to six years in prison for attempted robbery. Mckerry's criminal history dates back to age 12, with over 80 arrests by age 15. He was known for his prolific criminal activity, including stealing 22 charity boxes while dressed as a woman.

Four Royal Navy sailors were charged with gang rape of a young woman at a party in Canada. The four men were released on bail with the condition that they surrender their passports, live at a Canadian naval base, and continue to work for the Royal Navy. They are forbidden from contacting the victim or any witnesses and must remain in Nova Scotia. The investigation is ongoing and additional charges may be filed.

Valerie Jackson's son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare genetic skin disease that causes his skin to appear red and scaly.  This has led to people mistaking his condition for child abuse, resulting in police being called on Valerie.  She has also been subjected to taunts and stares from strangers, and RJ has been denied entry to play centers due to his condition.  Despite the challenges, Valerie remains positive and advocates for greater awareness of Netherton's syndrome.

Transport for London (TFL) has removed the Protein World "Are You Beach Body Ready?" advertisements from the London Underground. The ads featured a bikini-clad model and sparked controversy among feminists and body image campaigners. The Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints about the ads, and a Change.org petition calling for their removal garnered over 50,000 signatures. TFL stated that the ads were removed because the three-week advertising period paid for by Protein World had ended. The company also acknowledged the public reaction to the ads and said they would consider it in future advertising decisions.

Rail companies are raising fares by up to 87% despite promises from both major political parties to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western to request a review of their fare increases, which include an 87% increase on the route between London and the Cotswolds. Other companies, such as Virgin, have also raised fares, with some increases reaching 24.5%. The companies defend the increases by saying they are bringing fares in line with other services and that the increases affect only a small portion of their fares.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was blinded in one eye after being hit with a brick thrown at him by vandals. Young and his wife, Elaine, were at home in Oldham, Greater Manchester, when stones were thrown at their window. Young went outside to confront the vandals and was hit in the eye with a brick. Police are investigating the incident but believe it may have been a case of "messing around" with no motive.

Tom Poynton, a wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension after successfully returning from injuries sustained in a road accident that killed his father. Poynton missed the entire 2014 season due to the injuries but returned during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The club is pleased with his return and hopes the new contract will give him the confidence to perform well this summer.

Harley Renshaw, a five-year-old boy from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, after complaining of stomach pain. He underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. After a year of battling the disease, Harley has been declared cancer-free. He will continue to have regular check-ups to ensure the cancer does not return.

Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood believes that 19-year-old Jack Grealish should focus on his club career before making a decision about his international future. Grealish has been playing well for Aston Villa and is being pursued by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood wants Grealish to continue to play well for Aston Villa and believes that he will have to make a decision about his international future after playing more games for his club. Grealish's father, Kevin, agrees with Sherwood and believes that his son should focus on his club football first.

Landing fees for private jets vary greatly around the world. The most expensive airports for landing fees are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo being the most expensive at £4,559. Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo and Kansai International Airport in Osaka. The only British airport in the top 10 is Bristol Airport, which charges £2,929 per landing. The only US airport in the top 10 is LaGuardia Airport in New York, which charges £2,630. Other unexpected appearances in the top 10 include Dublin Airport and Salzburg Airport.

Katie Gallegos took her two dogs, Cooper and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy took a few licks, Cooper gobbled the rest of the cone in one bite. Gallegos says Cooper always eats quickly and makes sure Daisy gets her fill first. The video of Cooper eating the ice cream has been viewed over seven million times. Some viewers criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream, but she insists it is fine because Cooper is healthy and her previous dog, Sammy, lived to be 19 years old and enjoyed ice cream once a week. Gallegos also notes that the dogs have a penchant for fast food and another video shows them visiting a Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which is just whipped cream in a cup.

Gary Locke, former assistant manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed as the permanent manager after a successful interim period. He joined the club last summer as assistant to Allan Johnston, but took over as manager in February when Johnston resigned. Locke has a three-year contract and has only lost one game in seven since taking over.

A Florida mother is facing a school's threat to suspend her five-year-old autistic son for using essential oils to help him stay calm and focused. The school claims the oils are a distraction to other students, but the mother insists the oils have a positive impact on her son and that he has been using them all year without issue. The school district has since stated that they will not suspend the child, calling it a "health issue."

A fire destroyed a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton Beach, New York on Wednesday afternoon. The fire, which started near a car parked by the complex, spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed. The fire was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings and could be seen from three miles away. Firefighters were unable to enter the building due to the intensity of the flames, but they used cranes to approach the fire. The building manager, who lived and worked in the complex, lost everything in the fire.

Queen Elizabeth II, at 88 years old, continues to enjoy riding her fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park. She has been riding since she was four years old and has a long history of owning and breeding horses. While she has cut back on riding in recent years due to a knee injury, she remains an enthusiastic equestrian and is often seen at her Windsor stables. The Queen is known for her love of fell ponies, which she breeds at her Hampton Court stud. Fell ponies are a hardy breed that originated in Cumbria, England, and have been used for various purposes throughout history, including pack animals, riding horses, and even in trotting races.

A dispute over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbors escalated into a fatal altercation. Phillip Pama, a shift worker, allegedly punched Leon Yeaman, a pensioner, in the head after Yeaman refused to turn down his music. Yeaman died at the scene, and Pama was charged with manslaughter. Pama's lawyer stated that Yeaman was known for being loud and disruptive, and that Pama acted in self-defense. Pama was granted bail with conditions and the case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea's football manager, revealed that he prays every day but never about football. He also said that he tries to separate his professional and family life. Mourinho said he has a strong faith in God and prays for things in his personal life. He also said that he is a good person and tries to support people he doesn't even know.

Bob Barker, the original host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years. He hosted the first game, "Lucky Seven," before handing the hosting duties back to Drew Carey.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for attempted burglary and destruction of property. The incident occurred on Friday at 12:30 am on the 3200 block of D Street SE. Baldwin was arrested by Metropolitan Police officers returning to the scene of the alleged crime. The Secret Service revoked Baldwin's security clearance and placed him on leave. Baldwin is assigned to the Foreign Missions Branch, which works with the State Department on diplomatic activities. The arrest comes after a high-ranking supervisor was also placed on leave for alleged misconduct. The Homeland Security Department's Inspector General is investigating both incidents.

Atif Saeed, a freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture a photo of a lion at the city's safari park. Saeed crept within 10 feet of the lion, lying on the ground to get a good shot. The sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion to Saeed's presence, forcing him to retreat quickly. Saeed said he was trying to capture the lion's character and status, and that he wouldn't do it again.

The NYPD is trying to identify a woman who was found dead on March 22nd in Brooklyn. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. She had no identification on her, but had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg that investigators believe was the name "Monique" etched across a tattooed ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. The NYPD has released images of the tattoo in hopes of identifying the woman.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple, built a two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009. They were unable to afford a traditional home, so they built their own for $25,000. The home is powered by solar panels, with a gas-powered stove and hot water heater. Water comes from a nearby spring. The couple lives in Nelson, New Zealand, surrounded by nature.

A study by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten students who shared iPads in class scored significantly higher on early literacy tests than students who used iPads individually or did not use iPads at all. Blackwell believes that the collaborative learning aspect of sharing iPads is what leads to improved literacy scores. She suggests that schools reconsider how they use tablets, especially in early grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation in China after learning to walk on its front trotters. The piglet, nicknamed "Super Pig," has captured the hearts of thousands with its ability to balance and walk. The piglet belongs to farmer Ms. Duan, who noticed the piglet's missing legs when it was born. The piglet has become a local attraction, with villagers flocking to see the curious animal.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, a pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone. Dracone spun while exiting his pit box, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center and released after receiving stitches for a cut on his leg. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain prior to the start. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, after a fight in their apartment in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Severiano dragged his wife into the garden, slammed her head against the concrete 11 times, punched her in the face 10 times, and then shot her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the murder, stating that he was jealous of men looking at his wife. He was arrested after crashing a stolen car and faces life in prison.

Sarah Wilson, author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," revealed in an interview that she struggled with anxiety and came close to suicide. She attributed her mental health struggles to a combination of factors, including stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and feeling isolated from her family. Wilson believes that anxiety is becoming increasingly common and that it is often linked to depression. She encourages people to seek help if they are struggling with mental health issues.

Elena Curtin, a seven-months pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after she struck her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend in the head and arm with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin found her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom and asked her to leave, but the woman refused. Curtin then beat her with a crowbar. Oregon law allows for the use of physical force against an intruder who won't leave a resident's home. Prosecutors dropped the charge against Curtin because she was "completely justified in her outrage."

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust to a broccoli spear that her owner snuck into her treat mix. She chomped on the vegetable and then spit it out on the floor.  Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family when she is not eating.

HSBC apologized after a link on their official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were scrapped in 2011. The organizers allowed the registration for the website to expire, which allowed the pornographic site to take over the address. HSBC removed the hyperlink from their website and apologized for the inconvenience.

A 13-year-old boy, Marcus, called 911 after a fire broke out in his home in Clinton, Maryland. He and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, were trapped in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus calmly gave directions to firefighters, who rescued him and his sister through a window. The siblings were taken to Children's Hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

Pictures of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Australia's east coast have emerged. The images were taken in Jervis Bay, New South Wales, and show the neon glow illuminating a popular beach. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the sight as a "beautiful supernatural scene" caused by millions of plankton omitting light. A similar display occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. The glow is caused by *Noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in the spring and autumn.

New tests can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and predict the likelihood of recurrence. These tests, such as Endopredict, can identify patients with a low risk of recurrence, potentially sparing them from chemotherapy and its associated side effects. While these tests are currently available privately, experts believe they should be offered on the NHS due to cost savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy.

Over the past nine years, more than 25 women in the Royal Navy have been airlifted from ships due to pregnancy. This includes at least one woman from HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew. The data comes after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims she had a sexual relationship with a member of her crew. A Ministry of Defence spokesman confirmed there is a strict "no touching" rule in place at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave.  The Ministry of Defence would not confirm what action West would face.  Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990 and in 2014 around 9 per cent of personnel were female.  Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones.  Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant.  Ninety-nine servicewomen on operations were flown back to the UK between January 2006 and December 2013, and a further 102 women were evacuated from Iraq.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of the Japanese Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo. The drone was equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing the radioactive material. The discovery has raised concerns about the potential for terrorism involving drones, especially in light of the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. The Japanese government is reviewing drone regulations and plans to take steps to prevent terrorism.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because he is afraid she will get lost if left alone. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off. He rides slowly to work so they can chat and his mother feels safe. At work, he checks on her frequently. He feels it is his duty to care for his mother, who devoted her life to caring for her children.

A study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington found that heavy drinking among Americans rose 17.2% between 2005 and 2012. The study, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that the increase was largely due to rising rates among women. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. In 2012, 8% of Americans were considered heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. The study found that the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. Public health experts offer a number of cultural and economic explanations for the increase in excessive drinking, including changed social norms, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is warning that doctors are performing too many Cesarean sections, putting the health of mothers and babies at risk. The WHO recommends that Cesarean sections should only be performed when medically necessary, as they can lead to infections and even death. The WHO states that the ideal rate of Cesarean sections should be between 10% and 15%, but the rate in England has more than doubled since the early 1990s, with over 25% of women giving birth via Cesarean. The WHO also notes that Cesarean sections are more expensive than natural births and divert resources away from other patients.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham was arrested on April 17 after being found in the living room of a home she claimed to own. The owner, Mark Conklin, discovered Filkins in his $800,000 summer home in Edgartown, Martha's Vineyard. Filkins fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck after Conklin called the police. Police discovered a broken window covered by a blanket and arrested Filkins later that day after she attempted to re-enter the home. Filkins is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home, including a lamp and a painting, to return them to the Edgartown Police Department.

Bella Crooke lost her phone at a friend's birthday party. The phone was found by a security guard and turned into the Albury police station. Police officers used the unlocked phone to post selfies and puns on Bella's Facebook page in an attempt to find her. The posts included photos of the phone in various locations around the police station, including a holding cell. Bella eventually saw the posts and went to the police station to retrieve her phone. The police officers recognized her from her Facebook page and returned the phone to her. Bella was amused by the police's efforts and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as the calf was tossed into the air and dragged through the water. The mother had stayed with her herd during the fight, believing it was safer than intervening.  A tour operator, Stacey Farrell, witnessed the event and described how the mother tried to protect her calf from other hippos before the fatal attack.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000, a fraction of the price of neighboring homes. However, the property has only three years left on its lease. While the cost works out to be around the going rate for renting a three-bedroom flat in the area, extending the lease could make the property worth upwards of £6 million. The apartment is in need of renovation, but boasts 1,990 sq/ft of space, three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, and a utility room. Estate agents say it is rare for properties with such short leases to come on the market, and the phone has been ringing off the hook about the apartment. However, potential buyers should be aware that extending the lease will come with a massive premium.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing them to give away free drinks. The outage began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast. The company said the outage was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh and apologized for the inconvenience. The outage affected Starbucks, Evolution Fresh, and Teavana stores.

Terrorist training is taking place in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. Detective Constable Gareth Jones, from the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit, stated that those involved in these activities participate in seemingly ordinary activities within the community, but have an ulterior motive. He also stressed that terrorism is not confined to large cities, and that incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998.  Jones also mentioned that Michael Adebowale, one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences at Highmead, near Llanybydder.

An Omura's whale, a species rarely seen and thought to be extinct, was discovered on a beach in Western Australia. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. The whale was a juvenile female and was identified through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant because very little is known about the species, which was only scientifically described in 2003. The whale's carcass has been buried and will be recovered in a few years for further scientific investigation.

Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, believes that women should not be president because their hormones make them unfit for the job. She believes that women are more likely to start unnecessary wars due to their hormones. This view is not unique, as many people believe that women have a specific place in society and that place is not in leadership positions. However, studies show that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts. The article argues that the bias against women in the workplace is so ingrained that even in 2015, a female candidate will face an uphill battle to be elected. The article concludes that equality benefits everyone, including companies, families, and marriages.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and as Winston Churchill, is selling his collection of antiques at auction. The collection includes over 200 items, including a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, furniture, paintings, swords, rifles, silverware, and chandeliers. Hardy, a military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, is selling the collection because he is downsizing his home. The auction will take place on Saturday at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is wanted for the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, in Winter Garden, Florida. He was last seen fleeing on foot after failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son. Shemansky has a history of mental illness and was on parole for battery on law enforcement. He was reportedly seen asking for a glass of water at the trailer park office shortly after the murder. Authorities are asking anyone with information about his whereabouts to contact them at 407-656-3636.

The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) Council awarded Eugene, Oregon the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The council bypassed the usual bidding process because they saw a unique opportunity to host the championships in the United States for the first time. Eugene had previously failed to win the bid to host the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council was persuaded by Eugene's recent presentation and saw the opportunity to access a key market. This decision was made in the interest of the global development of athletics.

Leonie Granger, an aspiring model, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for the manslaughter of professional gambler Mehmet Hassan. Granger befriended Hassan at a casino and lured him back to his flat, where her boyfriend and an accomplice tied him up, beat him to death, and stole his winnings. Granger's co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life in prison with a minimum term of 36 years. The court heard that Hassan was a "soft target" who enjoyed the company of women and kept large sums of cash in his flat.

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season. His form has significantly dipped from the beginning of the season, when he looked likely to break the Premier League record for assists. Fabregas' former club, Barcelona, commented on his traditional post-Christmas slump, noting that his contributions to the team gradually decreased as each season drew to a close. Fabregas has only one assist in the last five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho will be hoping that Fabregas can find his form again in the final stretch of the season, as the team needs six wins from their remaining nine games to win the Premier League title.

West Ham is in talks to sign 17-year-old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford after he impressed during a trial with the club. Beckford, who has also received offers from clubs in Belgium, is considered one of the top prospects from the Caribbean. West Ham is also planning to offer the cheapest season tickets in the Premier League in an effort to fill their new 54,000-capacity stadium at the Olympic Stadium.

Mike Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, was assaulted by hunt saboteurs during a hunt on January 24th. Lane was kicked in the head and suffered concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. Despite a video of the incident and a dossier of evidence, including names and car registration numbers, Wiltshire police have dropped the investigation due to insufficient evidence. The police have stated that the case is undetected but will be reopened if further evidence comes to light.

Adam Gadahn, an American citizen, was killed in January in a U.S. counterterrorism operation. Gadahn was a prominent member of al Qaeda, known as "Azzam the American," and served as the organization's chief English-language propagandist. He was born in 1978 and converted to Islam in 1995. He left the United States for Pakistan in 1998 and joined al Qaeda, where he rose through the ranks. Gadahn appeared in numerous al Qaeda videos, urging Muslims to attack American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was indicted by a federal grand jury in California in 2006 for treason and material support to al Qaeda. Gadahn was married to a Muslim woman from Afghanistan and reportedly had at least one child.

Five-year-old Mai Zizhuo from China has become a viral sensation for his incredible basketball skills. The video shows him scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs at once, impressing viewers with his talent. His skills have earned him legions of fans across China, with many comparing him to the country's biggest basketball star, Yao Ming.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25th. O'Carroll was a key activist for PIE, which campaigned to legalize sex with children in the 1970s and 1980s. Hacked Off is a media pressure group that wants MPs to set up a statutory body to regulate the press.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained to host a fashion show for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The show featured a collection of ten unisex pieces designed to be worn in twenty different ways by the brand Ten Pieces, headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss. The show took place on a warm day with clear skies and featured models walking through the empty pool and along the break wall with the ocean as a backdrop.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, enjoyed a family trip to a safari park in Northern California. He posed with and fed a white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions. Khan announced that he will fight Chris Algieri on May 30th.

The name of a Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, was removed from an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism after his family and others complained. Abu Khdeir was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His family objected to his inclusion on the memorial wall, stating that no one asked for their permission. Almagor, an organization that works on behalf of victims of terror in Israel, also opposed Abu Khdeir's inclusion, describing his death as a rogue attack and not an act of terrorism. Following the complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel removed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial wall and website.

A young boy chases his cat around the garden, attempting to use the cat as a pillow. The cat, initially still, gets up and moves when the boy lays down on him. The boy follows the cat and repeats this action twice before the cat goes inside. Later, the boy is seen feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a witness in a Philadelphia police corruption trial, lost his coaching job at a private academy after testifying about his past drug dealing. Kushner, who had passed a background check when he was hired in 2010, testified that he was arrested in 2007 for selling marijuana and had the charges expunged as part of a probationary sentence. However, he was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. He also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Kushner claims he never intended to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges.

An explosion at a chemical plant in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province, China, injured six people and sparked a fire. The plant produces paraxylene (PX), a chemical used in the production of polyester films and fabrics. The explosion occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak. The fire was put out by over 600 firefighters. The plant was previously slated for Xiamen, but was relocated due to pollution concerns and protests.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa midfielder, is known for wearing his socks low and using children's shin pads. He says he will continue to do so because it is a superstition he has had his whole life. He has been told by referees to pull his socks up, but he refuses. Grealish made his first Premier League start against QPR and was pleased to finally get it out of the way.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has suffered global and irreversible brain damage. Though she is no longer in a medically induced coma, she remains unresponsive and does not react to visitors or familiar voices. She has a tracheostomy in her throat and her condition has not changed in nearly three months. While her father, Bobby Brown, stated that she is awake and watching him, her grandmother, Cissy Houston, and an attorney for the family said that she will have a long life but the quality of her life will not be known for years to come.

Russia is one win away from reaching the Fed Cup final after defeating Germany 2-0. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki in a hard-fought match that went to three sets, while Svetlana Kuznetsova defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Russia needs one more win on Sunday to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

New South Wales residents are being warned to brace for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. The storm is expected to bring heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday, potentially impacting the Hunter region, which was already hit hard by the previous storm. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that the new storm will hamper clean-up efforts, as they still have over 4,000 jobs to complete from the previous storm. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" music video, was hospitalized after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media reported that Moric attempted suicide and was found by her mother in her Milan apartment. However, Moric denied these claims on Instagram, stating that she fell and injured herself due to low blood pressure. She is recovering at home and reassured her fans that she is fine.

The British public is hoping for a baby princess and favors the name Diana for the second child of Kate and William. The poll revealed that 12% of people want the baby to be named after William's mother, Diana, the Princess of Wales. The second and third most popular names for a girl are Alice and Charlotte. For a boy, the most popular name is James, followed by Alexander. The poll also revealed that 68% of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and injured 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, in Khost, Afghanistan. The bombing occurred near a group of protesters who were on their way to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility for the attack.

Dani Alves will be leaving Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Alves has been with Barcelona for seven years, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League titles. His agent, Dinorah Santana, stated that Alves rejected a three-year contract extension that required him to play in 60% of the club's matches.

Boca Juniors forward Pablo Osvaldo has expressed his desire for former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes that the two Italian legends would be a good fit for Boca Juniors and that the fans would love to see them play at La Bombonera. He feels that Pirlo and Totti have a South American style of play and would be perfect for the club.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, had a spectacular fall from his horse at Wincanton, performing a double somersault. Despite the fall, he only sustained a cut on his nose and was back riding out the next day. Ferguson said he couldn't remember the fall and was shocked when he saw the replay. He joked that he might consider a career in gymnastics after racing.

James Haskell, captain of the London Wasps, posted a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram to celebrate the release of the new Avengers movie. Haskell, who returned to the Wasps in 2012 after playing rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has surpassed 100 appearances for the club and has become a key member of the England squad.

Wide-leg trousers are a popular trend for spring 2015. They are a welcome alternative to skinny jeans and can be styled in many ways. The key to pulling off the wide-leg trouser is to keep the top half simple and pair it with a high-heeled shoe. Denim is the easiest way to achieve the trend, and many designers, including Gucci, Celine, and Topshop, have incorporated wide-leg trousers into their spring 2015 collections.

The University of Michigan initially canceled a screening of the film "American Sniper" as part of a student social event series, UMIX, due to a petition signed by over 200 students who objected to the film's portrayal of the Iraq War. However, after a backlash and a counter-petition, the university reversed its decision, citing its commitment to freedom of expression and students' right to make their own choices. The university will also offer a screening of the family-friendly film "Paddington" for those who do not wish to attend "American Sniper."

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty after they allegedly set a quokka on fire on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia. The quokka, a small marsupial native to Australia, survived the incident but was singed by the flame. The tourists were evicted from the island and will appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer in New York City nightclubs, was able to see herself dancing for the first time.  Filmmakers from jazz-on-film.com compiled a video of "soundies" (early music videos) for Barker, who had lost all of her photographs and memorabilia.

A recent study found that a third of men in Britain have never washed their own car. The study also found that three-quarters of women never wash their own car. The decline in car washing is attributed to factors such as the rise of hand car washes, the size of modern cars, and the lack of time. The study found that people are more likely to wash their own cars during holidays, and that car owners in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield are more likely to wash their own cars than those in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh.

Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa on Sunday. If Liverpool wins, Gerrard will play in the final on his birthday, May 30th, before moving to LA Galaxy.  Martin Skrtel, a Liverpool defender, has praised Gerrard's impact on the team since he arrived in 2008. Skrtel believes Gerrard is one of the best players in the world and that Liverpool will be different without him. However, Skrtel believes that Liverpool has players who can replace Gerrard.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75 years old, aced the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This was his first ace on the course. Five aces were made during the contest, tying the record set in 2002. Nicklaus' ace was followed by Camilo Villegas, who also aced the fourth hole and the eighth hole.

On Wednesday night, tornadoes were reported in Kansas and Missouri. Spotters reported a tornado near Goddard, Kansas, which moved northeast, missing Wichita but posing a threat to other communities.  Tornadoes were also reported in southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. In Missouri, a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, and downed trees.  More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday.
