Johanna Braddy is an actress who starred in the web series "Video Game High School" and the Lifetime series "Unreal." She currently stars in the ABC thriller "Quantico."

Martin Van Buren was the eighth President of the United States, serving from 1837 to 1841. He was a member of the Democratic Party and held other high-ranking positions, including Vice President and Secretary of State, under President Andrew Jackson. Van Buren was a key supporter of Jackson's 1828 presidential campaign and ran for Governor of New York to help boost Jackson's popularity. After serving as governor for two months, Van Buren resigned to become Jackson's Secretary of State. Following his resignation as Secretary of State, Jackson appointed Van Buren as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey is home to two universities: Rutgers University-Camden, founded in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School, and Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan is the tenth most populous state in the U.S. and the largest state east of the Mississippi River. It is the only state with two peninsulas, making it a popular destination for recreational boating.

Penguin Books revolutionized publishing in the 1930s by selling inexpensive paperbacks through stores like Woolworths for sixpence, making high-quality fiction and non-fiction accessible to the masses.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who helped make country music popular worldwide. The film, based on Salama's own experiences, was initially deemed too sensitive by the censorship board and Salama was forced to adjust the script while trying to preserve the film's core concept of religious discrimination.

The song was leaked before its official release, but Gaga debuted the final version at Alexander McQueen's Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009. The song was a worldwide success, topping charts in many countries and selling 12 million copies worldwide, making it one of the best-selling singles of all time. They have also released other popular films like Monsters vs. Aliens, Rise of the Guardians, The Croods, and Home. DreamWorks Animation also created the animated television series Trollhunters for Netflix.

Chris Eubank, born in 1966, is a former British professional boxer who competed from 1985 to 1998. His son, Chris Eubank Jr., born in 1989, is also a British professional boxer. Eubank Jr. has held the IBO super-middleweight title since 2017, and has previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017, Eubank Jr. is ranked as the world's fifth best super middleweight by BoxRec, seventh best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.
Sophia Anna Bush is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, known for her roles in the films *John Tucker Must Die*, *The Hitcher*, and *The Narrows*.

James Murdoch is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and the chairman of Sky plc. He is the son of Rupert Murdoch, the chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and former chairman and CEO of News Corporation, the world's second-largest media conglomerate.

Creedence Clearwater Revival, also known as Creedence or CCR, was an American rock band that was active from the late 1960s to the early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are bony growths on the heel bone that are typically detected by an x-ray.
The South Wales Coalfield, located in south Wales, is a large region with abundant coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual football competition for the top clubs in North America, Central America, and the Caribbean. It was originally called the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when it began in 1962.

Mary of Teck became Queen Mother after her husband's death in 1936. She supported her son, George VI, after her eldest son, Edward, abdicated to marry Wallis Simpson. She died in 1953 during the reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
The film "Poseidon" made $181,674,817 worldwide, exceeding its $160 million budget.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first awarded in 1996. Omar Epps and Joe Morton are tied for the most wins with three each.

Human trafficking is the trade of humans for forced labor, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation. The International Labour Organization estimates that forced labor alone generates $150 billion in profits annually. Of the estimated 21 million victims of human trafficking, 68% are exploited for labor, 22% are sexually exploited, and 10% are exploited in state-imposed forced labor.
The animated film *Rio* was released in 2011 and had a sequel, *Rio 2*, released on April 11, 2014.

Francis I, King of France from 1515-1547, was known as "Francis of the Large Nose" and the "Knight-King" for his involvement in wars against Holy Roman Emperor Charles V.  He formed an alliance with the Ottoman Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, a controversial move for a Christian king.  The Italian War of 1536-1538 was a conflict between Francis I and Charles V.  There was also a Holy Roman Emperor named Francis I, who reigned from 1708-1765, but his wife held the real power.

Peking University (PKU), located in Beijing, is China's first modern national university. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking, it replaced the ancient Taixue or Guozijian, and served as China's Ministry of Education. PKU is consistently ranked as the top higher learning institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was known for his mutton chops, gravelly voice, and unique bass playing style.
Global warming has significant effects on humans, including threats to food security due to decreasing crop yields and the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.
"Australia" is a 2008 film directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman. The film is an epic historical romantic drama.
Michael Vick is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles. He was born on June 26, 1980.

Canadian folklore encompasses a wide range of traditions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices like traditional food and craft making. Folklore also includes oral traditions such as tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining. They also trained combat cameramen.

James Jones is the name of both an author and a basketball player. The author, James Jones, won the 1952 National Book Award for his novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was adapted into a film and later a television series. The basketball player, James Jones, averaged 25 points per game in his senior year, earning Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors. He has won three NBA championships and finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage during the 2007-2008 season.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Computer animation is the process of creating animated images. The American television series "Trollhunters" is a computer-animated fantasy series created by Guillermo del Toro for Netflix. It was produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE in 2009, with his resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the fourth Doctor in the science fiction series *Doctor Who* from 1974 to 1981, a longer tenure than any other actor. He is also known for narrating the comedy series *Little Britain*. Baker has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.
Hanford Site is a large area in Washington state that is home to a variety of facilities, including a commercial nuclear power plant, scientific research centers, and a cleanup project.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed by the President to act as spokesperson for the executive branch. The Press Secretary briefs the media on the President, senior executives, and policies, making it a prominent non-Cabinet position.

Kentucky, nicknamed the "Bluegrass State" due to its fertile soil, is home to the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky. This region houses two major cities, Louisville and Lexington. Kentucky is also known for its horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston.  Preston also starred in the films The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper. She is also known by the stylized name Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of the song "Despacito" were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and MOSKA, and an urban version by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and eventually broadcast via pay-per-view television. In 1987, the WWF scheduled a pay-per-view of their own, Survivor Series, on Thanksgiving night and demanded exclusivity from cable providers on carriage of the event. From 1987, Starrcade was broadcast on pay-per-view, the first NWA event to do so. The WWE Network included the previous Starrcades (1983-1986), which had been transmitted via closed-circuit television, alongside the rest of the Starrcades in the pay-per-view section, and rated the show as TV-MA due to the amount of violence in the matches.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director who works in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first Star Trek series developed for the streaming service CBS All Access and the first since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews was a professional football player who played defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins. He also played in the World League of American Football for Rhein Fire.

French Montana's debut studio album is titled *Excuse My French*.  The 2014 Egyptian comedy film *Excuse My French* is directed by Amr Salama and based on his experiences at a public middle school in Egypt.  British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, known as Plan B or Ben Drew, was born on October 22, 1983.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or just disk, is a type of disk storage made of a thin, flexible magnetic medium sealed in a rectangular plastic case. The case is lined with fabric to remove dust particles.

Guatemala experienced political instability and civil strife from the mid-19th century to the late 20th century. From 1960 to 1996, a civil war was fought between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, resulting in the genocide of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are a handheld, hinged instrument used for grasping and holding objects. They are also known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The seventh and final season of the television series "The Closer" began on Monday, July 11, 2011. The show had finished its sixth season as the highest-rated drama on cable television.

Dr. Jack Shephard is the main character in the television series *Lost*, played by Matthew Fox. The show aired on ABC from 2004 to 2010 and had an average of 16 million viewers per episode in its first season.

Matthew McConaughey is an American actor born on November 4, 1969. Since 2011, he has focused on dramatic roles in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer*, *Bernie*, *Killer Joe*, *The Paperboy*, *Mud*, *Magic Mike*, *The Wolf of Wall Street*, *Dallas Buyers Club*, *Interstellar*, *The Sea of Trees*, and *Free State of Jones*.  *Mud* (2012) stars Matthew McConaughey, Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer, music journalist, record producer, and musician. He is best known for his book *Deep Blues*, his work for the *New York Times* and *Rolling Stone*, and his clarinet playing in the band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who is best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum, died in 1941. Gutzon Borglum designed the sculpture and oversaw its construction from 1927 to 1941 with the help of his son, Lincoln. After Gutzon's death, Lincoln took over as leader of the project.

The film "Underdog" is directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. The film stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens from a space habitat called "The Ark" who are among the first to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on the teens' parents, including Clarke's mother, Dr. Abby Griffin, and the Chancellor of the Ark, Thelonious Jaha.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a successful humanitarian aid project that raised awareness and funds for refugees in Bangladesh. Despite financial difficulties, it inspired future projects like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is a highly influential Indian filmmaker who is credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and changing the landscape of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was a statement made by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates in 1858. The debates were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, who were running for the United States Senate from Illinois. The debates were widely attended, as the issue of slavery was a major concern for people across the nation.

"Easy A" is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. The film stars Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her writing career with the publication of *Interview with the Vampire* in 1976. While her early works received mixed reviews, she gained popularity in the 1980s. She was married to poet and painter Stan Rice for 41 years until his death in 2002.

Camden, New Jersey is the 12th most populous municipality in the state, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 census. At the beginning of the 20th century, Camden's population was primarily made up of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film *The Canyons*, which was directed by Paul Schrader. *The Canyons* is an American erotic thriller-drama film.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate from Illinois, and incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas, the Democratic Party candidate. The debates were held in seven towns in Illinois.

Homer is credited with writing the Iliad and the Odyssey, two epic poems considered central to ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was murdered on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a band formed by Chris Cornell (Soundgarden) and members of Rage Against the Machine: Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he is a member of Prophets of Rage. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. Her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, was released in 2010 by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town in Louisiana that is the parish seat of East Carroll Parish. The University of Mississippi has a student body that is 55% undergraduate and 60% overall from Mississippi. 23% of the student body are minorities and international students come from 90 nations.
The TV series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, which is set to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in various political roles in New York, including the State Assembly, Attorney General, and U.S. Senator. He reached the pinnacle of his career as Vice President of the United States.

The Soyuz spacecraft was designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s as part of the Soviet space program. It was originally intended for the Soviet manned lunar programs and replaced the Voskhod spacecraft. The Soyuz has been in service since the 1960s and has been used for both unmanned and manned launches.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine's fourth studio album, *Renegades*, was released in 2000.  The band broke up in 2000 after lead singer Zack de la Rocha left due to creative differences.  De la Rocha began a solo career while the rest of the band formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell.  Audioslave disbanded in 2007, the same year Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a stock market index that tracks the performance of 30 large and financially stable companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. One of these companies is Tata Motors, which is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the 14th most populous country in the world with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants. Vietnam borders China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced high economic growth and is one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.
Bhagat Singh was an Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero after his death. He was executed at age 23 for two acts of violence against the British in India.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 film "Dangal," a biographical sports drama directed by Nitesh Tiwari. "Dangal" is about wrestling and features Aamir Khan.

James VI of Scotland became James I of England and Ireland in 1603, uniting the crowns of the two countries. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states, James ruled both in a personal union. He advocated for a single parliament for both countries, but faced difficulties with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack is a New Zealand actress known for her roles in television series such as *Shortland Street*, *Xena: Warrior Princess*, *The Cult*, and *Legend of the Seeker*. She has also appeared in films such as *Separation City* and the Australian series *Rake*. Cormack is best known for her role as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama *Wentworth*, which she starred in for four years before leaving in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer known for his work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who has starred in several films, including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

Lady Gaga's album *Artpop* received mixed reviews but was commercially successful. It debuted at number one on the Billboard 200 chart, selling 258,000 copies in its first week. It was Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the United States and sold 757,000 copies overall. *Artpop* was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, selling 2.3 million copies worldwide.
John Frusciante's last album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers was *Stadium Arcadium*, released in 2006. Frusciante left the band in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher was the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She is considered one of the most influential politicians in British history, but her policies remain controversial.
Michael McKagan is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. In addition to his musical career, McKagan has written weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain. It has a population of around 800,000 in the administrative center and a metropolitan area population ranging from 1.7 to 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, also known as the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community of Spain.
Buffy Summers is a character who was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The television series "Make It or Break It" ended after three seasons, with the final episode airing on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a field that uses computer science, linguistics, and electrical engineering to translate spoken language into text. SR is used in a variety of applications, including voice user interfaces, search, data entry, and speech-to-text processing. The field has seen significant advances due to the adoption of deep learning methods by companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf, an American businessman and former comic book store owner, co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International in 1970 and served as its chairman. The convention was originally called the Golden State Comic Book Convention and was founded by a group of San Diegans including Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

The Turkish Airlines Open is currently underway, with France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl tied for the lead at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy is in third place at 15 under par, after shooting a third consecutive 67. McIlroy is looking to win his first title since May and believes he can shoot a low round on the final day. He is currently leading the Race to Dubai standings, with three events remaining.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain's main opposition group al-Wefaq, believes that national dialogue is necessary to resolve the country's political crisis. He believes that the government must show its willingness to offer concrete solutions and that the Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa, seen as a reformist, should be involved in the dialogue. Salman believes that the only way forward is to work with reformists within the royal family, including the Crown Prince, who has long been considered a proponent of accommodation with the country's Shia majority. He also calls for the release of 13 opposition leaders and human rights activists who have been sentenced to between five years and life in prison on evidence widely accepted as having been obtained under torture.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He was considered a leading figure in the early-music movement, having worked with numerous orchestras worldwide and directed the AAM for over 30 years. Hogwood's contributions included the AAM's recording of the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and his 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah, which is considered one of the top 20 recordings of all time. He was also a respected academic, holding positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities. Hogwood's legacy is remembered by colleagues and musicians who credit him with fostering a new generation of musicians and promoting historically informed music.

Homicide rates in Scotland have decreased, with 57 victims recorded in the year ending March 2016, the lowest number since 1976. This is half the number recorded nine years ago. Sharp instruments, primarily knives, were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. While most accused individuals had unknown alcohol and drug status, 31% were identified as being under the influence. The Justice Secretary emphasized the need for continued efforts to combat violence, including education and enforcement, while acknowledging the role of public services and law enforcement in supporting communities and addressing irresponsible attitudes towards alcohol and violence. However, Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman expressed caution, noting that previous homicide figures were revised upwards, and highlighted the increase in sexual crime and violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost their game against Sunderland 2-1, making them the first team to lose to Sunderland in the Premier League this season. Bournemouth had many scoring opportunities but were unable to capitalize on them, despite Sunderland playing with 10 men after Steven Pienaar was dismissed.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has defended his country's policy of detaining migrants who arrive by boat, saying it is the only way to prevent deaths at sea. The New York Times has criticized the policy as "brutal" and "inhumane," but Abbott has stood by his comments. He has also drawn criticism for comparing the Islamic State to the Nazis, saying that the Islamic State is worse because they boast about their evil.

The US has suspended talks with Russia regarding the Syrian ceasefire due to Russia’s failure to uphold its commitments to the agreement. The US blames Russia and the Syrian government for escalating attacks against civilians, including the bombing of Aleppo’s main trauma hospital. Russia denies involvement in the attacks and accuses the US of failing to fulfill its obligations to the agreement. The US has withdrawn personnel from the Joint Implementation Center, but the two sides will continue to discuss counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

The Policy Exchange think tank has proposed a plan to sell high-value social housing to raise funds for building new social housing. The plan would raise £4.5 billion annually, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. The plan has been supported by the Prime Minister's office, but criticized by Labour, who argue that it would displace low-income families from desirable neighborhoods. The think tank argues that the plan would create the largest social housing building program since the 1970s and reduce the number of people on the social housing waiting list by 500,000.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, the city at the center of a measles epidemic. While laboratory tests confirmed a diagnosis of measles, further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash shortly after being discharged. His family said he had no known contact with measles, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.
Vincent Hudson, 54, was charged with a historical offense against a boy under 16. The alleged attack occurred in 2001 and Hudson is scheduled to appear in North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.
Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in a National League match. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute when Jake Lawlor scored. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute when Wes York scored.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of Bristol's football club, has received approval from Bristol City Council to replace two stands at the stadium, increasing its capacity. This plan is an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed. The work is expected to begin in May, after a six-week judicial review period.

Cuadrilla, the company behind the fracking operation in Lancashire, has suspended drilling after a 1.5 magnitude earthquake, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining the data collected from the tremors and will determine if the drilling should resume. The BGS has stated that any process that injects pressurized water into rocks at depth can cause earthquakes. The latest tremor was felt by at least one person in Poulton-le-Fylde and occurred at a depth of approximately 1.2 miles.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner draped on his bagpipes in April 2015. Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and that the banner was a tribute to the victims, not an attempt to deceive anyone. The Hillsborough Justice Campaign confirmed that Carpenter had permission to display the banner but not to collect funds for the charity. Carpenter will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0. Grant Ward scored the first goal for Ipswich, followed by Luke Varney and Tom Lawrence. QPR's keeper, Alex Smithies, miscued a clearance, allowing Varney to score. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy was pleased with the win, especially Varney's performance. QPR manager Ian Holloway blamed the second goal for the loss, but also criticized his team's mental toughness. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place in the Championship, while QPR fell to 15th.

Tom Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, is excited to join the club because of its positive direction and the elite performance environment created by the coaches. Wells had a successful T20 Blast season last year, scoring 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66.

The Redruth Rugby team, currently fifth in National Two South, defeated third-placed Chinnor 29-12, marking their second consecutive win.  The team's strong performance was attributed to the leadership of Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, particularly their impressive tackling.  The Reds face a challenging schedule with seven games against lower-ranked teams and a match against league leaders Old Elthamians.  Despite the win, coach  Churcher believes the team has room for improvement and emphasizes the importance of building upon their recent success.

Nazrul, a 28-year-old Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested in Kolkata for the rape of a 74-year-old nun. He is the sixth person arrested in connection with the crime, which occurred on March 14th in Ranaghat town. The attack involved the theft of money from the convent school and the ransacking of the building before the nun was raped. Police have identified eight suspects in the attack, two of whom remain at large.

This interactive video, created by the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, explores the reasons why consumer buying habits change. The video focuses on the impact of new technologies like the domestic freezer, the introduction of washing powder, and cheaper imports on the types of products available and popular in the UK. The interactive elements also examine the shifting ownership and ranking of major UK brands.

Two elderly women in Scotland were tricked by phone scammers claiming to be from BT technical support. The scammers gained remote access to their computers and stole money. Police are warning people to be cautious of cold calls and never give out banking information over the phone.

Featherstone Rovers have hired former Swinton Lions coach, John Duffy, on a one-year contract. Duffy, who has a long playing career, will lead Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell is excited to see how Duffy's reign unfolds, praising his work at Swinton. Duffy has been replaced at Swinton by his former assistant, Stuart Littler.

On Sunday at 12:50 GMT, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter responded to a call at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve. The rider, who had head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand, was treated and flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency for satellite tracking of planes. This will allow for real-time tracking of aircraft anywhere in the world, improving upon the current system which relies on ground-based radars and leaves 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The decision was made in response to the disappearance of MH370 in 2014, which exposed weaknesses in worldwide air navigation systems. The new system will require aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes, or more in case of emergency.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found alive at age 18. His father, Bobby Hernandez, was arrested and charged with tampering with records in Ohio. Authorities suspect Bobby Hernandez was involved in Julian's disappearance in 2002.

A fire at a waste facility in Duncan Street on March 2nd caused travel delays and prompted the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective August 7th, after determining the company was "broadly compliant" with fire safety regulations but had not addressed concerns raised by the fire service regarding the potential impact of a fire on nearby residents, transportation, and the environment. The company has until August 7th to appeal the decision.

Russia is considering two new bills that would allow for the annexation of territories from neighboring countries. The first bill would allow for the annexation of a territory if its people express a desire to join Russia. The second bill would expedite the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speakers, who are seen as vulnerable to a "brown threat." These bills are being considered in response to the current crisis in Ukraine, where pro-Russian sentiment is strong in the Crimea region.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, is currently experiencing a period of decline. The team has won 182 grands prix, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, but their recent performance has been disappointing. The slump began in 2013 with issues in chassis design, and despite improvements in the car, the Honda power unit has been a major obstacle. McLaren's greatest successes came during their partnership with Honda, including a dominant season in 1988. However, the team has faced scandals and setbacks in recent years, including a constructors' championship ban in 2007 and a "lie-gate" incident in 2009. Despite these challenges, McLaren's CEO Ron Dennis believes that the team is on the verge of a comeback, with a strong car and a renewed partnership with Honda. The team's success hinges on the performance of the Honda engine and the ability to arrest the decline.

Thomas Baker, 44, was shot and killed in Liverpool on January 27th.  Police believe the three suspects, aged 29 and 32, had been waiting outside the Phoenix Gym for an hour before the shooting.  The suspects fled the scene in a silver VW Polo, which was last seen traveling along Balmoral Road, Molyneux Road, and Queens Road.  Police are asking anyone who may have seen the shooting or the car to come forward.

This article discusses five ways to enjoy Christmas online, including virtual church services, a fantasy game, nativity videos, and Manga versions of the Bible. The article highlights the use of technology to spread religious messages and connect with communities during the holiday season.

A public inquiry is being held to determine whether a proposed motorsports circuit can be built on 250 hectares of common land in Ebbw Vale. The developers have offered 320 hectares of replacement land, but experts disagree on whether the replacement land is of equal value and whether the circuit would damage habitats. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation, and the Welsh government will ultimately decide whether the project can proceed.

Chechen Muslim clerics have condemned a report by Novaya Gazeta alleging the persecution of homosexuals in Chechnya, calling it an insult to their faith and demanding retribution against the paper. The report, which detailed the detention and torture of over 100 men suspected of being gay, has been corroborated by the Russian LGBT Network, who are helping victims flee the region. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov has denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network has accused the Russian authorities of ignoring the abuses and has threatened to file a case at the International Criminal Court if no action is taken.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, receives housing benefit payments by finding properties for single homeless men. The agency is partnered with Fresh Start Housing, a charity that refers clients from London homeless charities. The letting agency makes money by placing multiple unrelated people in one house and charging housing benefit for each person, resulting in a higher total benefit payout than the rent fee passed on to the landlord. Investing Solutions is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making the venture highly profitable. The company focuses on providing housing to single homeless men over 35, as they are eligible for private rather than shared accommodation, allowing the agency to charge higher rent. However, tenants have reported living in unsuitable properties with issues such as lack of heating, hot water, rats, and damp. The agency has been criticized for prioritizing profit over the well-being of tenants.

Great Britain lost their final warm-up game for the Eurobasket qualifying campaign to the Netherlands, 76-71. The Netherlands outscored Great Britain 10-0 in the fourth quarter to secure the win. Coach Joe Prunty was pleased with the performance of Ben Gordon, who scored 13 points, including three consecutive three-pointers in the third quarter. Prunty stated that the key to the qualifying campaign will be to play hard on both ends of the court.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) will debate whether to allow 8oz gloves for the upcoming fight between Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather Jr. The NAC has received a waiver request from McGregor, who wants to use lighter gloves, but the commission is concerned about the safety of the fighters. The NAC will make a decision on August 16th.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, is losing its last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post. The street was once a bustling hub of activity, with nearly every national newspaper having offices there. However, the rise of television and social media, coupled with the move of newspapers to new locations and the adoption of new technology, led to the decline of Fleet Street. The departure of the last two journalists marks the end of an era for British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter series, has been the target of online abuse after donating to the "No" campaign in the Scottish independence referendum. She has been called a "traitor" and has blocked some abusive Twitter users. However, she has also interacted with other SNP supporters and found common ground with them politically.

A study by the University of Edinburgh found that children from deprived backgrounds are more likely to be involved in crime and violence. The study, which tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998, found that children from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely to face police action as wealthier children who commit the same crime. They were also five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. The study also found that poverty increases the risk of violence, and that contact with the juvenile justice system can inadvertently reproduce the conditions in which violence can flourish. Despite a recent fall in crime rates in Scotland, the study found that crime is still highly concentrated amongst poor people and within poor neighborhoods. This raises questions about whether inequality is being adequately tackled by the Scottish government.

Robbie Walsh was charged with assault causing serious harm to Karl Haugh, who was stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee. Walsh was one of three people who entered the estate looking for Haugh, and a fight ensued where weapons were used. Haugh was pronounced dead at the hospital after receiving a stab wound to the back. Police recovered a knife handle and a blade with blood on it at the scene. Walsh was remanded in custody until August 14th.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted a false accusation against Tom Elliott, a member of the UDR and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone. The tweet alleged that Elliott had harassed and shot people during his time in the UDR. Elliott was alerted to the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and apologized, admitting the tweet was untrue. Elliott is seeking compensation for the damage caused by the tweet.

Hawick Knitwear, a company founded in 1874, has seen a surge in demand for its sweaters, both for its own brand and for private label clients. The company has increased production to 9,500 sweaters per week to meet this demand, up from 7,500 last year. This success is attributed to the dedicated staff and the company's strong sales both domestically and internationally.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial for causing serious injury by dangerous driving after he hit 72-year-old Sylvia Blackburn, a lollipop lady, with his car. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care.

NATO is conducting an anti-submarine warfare exercise in the North Atlantic, simulating a hunt for a German U-boat. The exercise is a response to the growing threat from Russian submarines, which have been increasingly active in the region. The exercise highlights a significant gap in Britain's defenses, as they no longer have any maritime patrol aircraft, which are crucial for anti-submarine warfare. Russia has been investing heavily in its submarine fleet, which is now considered to be the most advanced in the world. The exercise is a reminder that NATO needs to be prepared to conduct anti-submarine warfare, and that some nations, including Britain, cannot do it alone.

The violence in South Sudan has caused a humanitarian crisis, with over 340,000 people fleeing to neighboring Uganda, more than any other country this year. The violence has been fueled by ethnic tensions, with the Dinka targeting the Equatorians and Nuer. Refugees report widespread killings, rapes, and the targeting of civilians. The violence has spread to the previously peaceful southern Equatoria states, forcing many to flee their homes. Uganda has been generous in its response, providing refugees with shelter, land, and access to education. However, the influx of refugees is straining resources, and the international community is being urged to pressure South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

On November 12th, 38-year-old boxer, Clinton McKenzie, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall. McKenzie, a former football player, began his boxing career in 2013 and has a record of 8 wins and 1 draw. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital, built in 1813, is being replaced with a new £33 million facility. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray, and space for mobile scanners. The new hospital is part of the coalition's £330 million investment for new NHS facilities across England. The remaining balance of the project will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Sheffield. The victim was found in or near a black Mercedes he was driving. The shooting occurred during a family celebration, and residents reported hearing a gunshot and rushing to help the victim. This incident is one of several shootings that have occurred in Sheffield in recent weeks, though previous incidents were in the north of the city.

The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International are three groups of hackers who have been active in the conflict in Ukraine. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have used DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and have hacked into CCTV systems and network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, a pro-Russian group, has hacked into Ukrainian government websites and electronic billboards to spread anti-Ukrainian propaganda. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, has published leaked documents from the Kremlin, including emails from a former Russian FSB colonel.

Several MSPs, including former First Minister Alex Salmond, Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick, and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil, are stepping down from the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond used his final speech to reiterate his belief that Scotland is diverse, not divided, and that the parliament should assume greater responsibility for governing the country. McNeil warned that Holyrood needs to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system, to ensure accountability and scrutiny.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She will be gathering information from pensioners, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations for improving care. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Rochira acknowledges the positive impact of high-quality care, she has also received concerns about variations in care quality across Wales. The review aims to ensure that those responsible for care services understand the realities of living in residential care and take action to improve the quality of life for older people.

Harbro Group, a Turriff-based company that manufactures and supplies animal feeds and operates 19 Country Store locations across Scotland, saw pre-tax profits increase to £3.5 million in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million decrease in turnover. The company attributes this to growth in international sales, both in Europe and new markets. While the company acknowledges the challenging agricultural climate, they are confident in their ability to navigate the uncertainties of Brexit.

Police are investigating a murder that occurred in Little Gaddesden, Hertfordshire. A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road. A man in his 80s was also taken to the hospital. Police are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the murder. They have warned the public not to approach him.
The IMF is likely to downgrade its global growth forecast to below 3.4% due to a weakening global economy. This comes after China's trade figures showed a significant decline in exports.

The new chain ferry in Cowes has experienced numerous problems since its launch on May 14th, including breakdowns, running aground, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Cars have also been damaged while boarding and disembarking. The council has ordered an audit of the project and is offering free crossings until July 2nd to allow for feedback. The council is also considering compensation for local businesses who have suffered losses due to the ferry's problems.

A fatal car crash occurred on Thursday morning on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel. A 32-year-old man was killed in the crash, and a 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed for several hours while police investigated the scene.

Matching Models, a London temp agency, has been criticized for its discriminatory job advertisements. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) called the agency's ads "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" and is investigating their hiring practices. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the ads, stating that "looks are important" to their clients. Employment lawyer James Lynas said the ads are "clearly unlawful" and that anyone could complain to the EHRC. The EHRC stated that employers are not allowed to discriminate based on age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children, disability, race, or religion. Jansen defended the agency's practices, stating that clients have specific requests, such as a "Jackie O" look for a personal assistant and blonde, blue-eyed Greek women for a businessman.

A shooting occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, India. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, shot and killed 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and remanded until April 12th. While gun crime is rare in India, the incident follows a 2007 shooting at a school near Delhi where a 14-year-old student was killed by two classmates.

Glaad's "Where We Are on TV" study found that there were 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters on television between June 2016 and May 2017. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16, but over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off. The report also found a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has announced he will not seek re-election. This decision comes after a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The MP was criticized for his role in a loan to Northampton Town Football Club from the borough council, which is now subject to a police investigation.  The loan, intended to rebuild Sixfields stadium and develop nearby land, is missing £10.25 million, and the stand remains half built.

Roy Oliver, a former police officer in Balch Springs, Texas, was indicted for murder in the shooting death of 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. The shooting occurred in April when police responded to a house party. Oliver fired into a car full of teenagers as they left the party, killing Edwards and injuring his brothers. The initial police report claimed the car reversed aggressively towards Oliver, but video footage showed the car driving forward. Oliver was also charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. If convicted, Oliver would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973.

Melania Trump has decided to stay in New York with Barron until he finishes school, making her the third First Lady in history to not live in the White House during her husband's presidency. While some have criticized her decision, others have defended it, saying it is a responsible choice for a parent. The article goes on to discuss how other First Ladies have handled their roles and families while living in the White House, including Frances Folsom Cleveland, Dolley Madison, and Michelle Obama. The article concludes by stating that the White House can be whatever the family makes it, and that both Hillary Clinton and Michelle Obama were able to balance their duties as First Lady with their children's needs.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on October 27th. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) is investigating the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaits the findings.

The Met Office issued a yellow warning for strong winds, with gusts up to 75 mph, particularly west of the mountains. The unusual easterly direction of the wind could exacerbate the impact. Travel disruptions on roads and at sea are likely. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey due to overnight gusts, closing a main route into the town. Telford Road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Nottingham Panthers and the Sheffield Giants played a close game, with the Giants winning 4-3. The Giants were short-handed for the opener, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game for the Panthers. Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal to put the Panthers ahead, but Andy Bohmback tied the game again. Mike Radja and James Desmarais scored for the Giants, while David Ling scored for the Panthers. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

Lewis Hamilton started from the back of the pack and had a disastrous race, suffering a broken front wing on the first lap and making five pit stops. Despite this, he is confident he can close the 36-point gap to Nico Rosberg in the remaining 18 races. Rosberg won the race after Ricciardo's puncture allowed him to take the lead. Vettel finished second after a collision with Raikkonen on the first lap, and Raikkonen finished fifth after a strong comeback.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, came out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit. His announcement was praised by many, including former teammates, football administrators, and politicians. Hitzlsperger's announcement is seen as a watershed moment in Germany, which has struggled with homophobia in football. The announcement has sparked hope that it will lead to greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Brighton midfielder,  Liam Sidwell, hopes to sign a new contract with the team after helping them achieve promotion to the Premier League. Sidwell has played 32 Championship games this season and believes he deserves another chance to play in the Premier League. He has previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke.

Blackpool and Colchester United tied 1-1. Blackpool scored first after 12 minutes when Nathan Delfouneso passed to Jamille Matt, who scored. Colchester tied the game after 17 minutes when Kurtis Guthrie scored after a goalmouth scramble. Colchester had a chance to take the lead before halftime, but Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made a save. Blackpool had a chance to win the game 15 minutes before the end, but Tom Aldred missed a header. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was red-carded for a bad tackle.

Colchester United signed 29-year-old defender, Luke Reid, who previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid could make his debut for the U's in their EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester lost their first game of the season to Accrington 3-1.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is raising £1.5 million to build a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in honor of the more than 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the line of duty over the past 250 years. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out for families of fallen officers, and the government has committed £1 million to the project. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United won their match against Sunderland 1-0, extending their lead at the top of the table to 15 points with eight games remaining. Manager Alex Ferguson stated that the team is focused on the games ahead, not the past, and that they will be going into the derby against Manchester City with a 15-point lead. Ferguson will make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea. He also mentioned that Wayne Rooney was tired after returning from international duty and that Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available for the match.

Google paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, which Google CEO Eric Schmidt claims is the legally required amount. Schmidt believes that companies should pay the taxes that are legally required and that it is up to the government to change the tax system if they want companies to pay more. He also argues that corporate taxes should be levied in the country where the company conducts economic activity and takes risks, rather than where products are consumed.

The NHS is trying to reduce its reliance on agency staff, which cost the service £3.6 billion last year. A cap was introduced in October that has saved £600 million, but the NHS is still £1 billion short of its goal. The regulator, NHS Improvement, is publishing league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending and collecting information on the 20 highest-earning agency staff per trust.

Longford Town Centre, once a thriving commercial hub, is now struggling to recover from the economic downturn. While local businesses are seeing signs of improvement, they believe more needs to be done to boost the economy. The government is promoting tourism with the Center Parcs development, but local businesses are calling for more support, including free parking. The opposition party criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, arguing that investment should be focused on broadband improvement rather than water meters.

The tournament consists of eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four teams advancing to the playoffs. The competition concludes on May 29th in the same stadium.  The tournament features four current or former England players: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen.  The tournament schedule is provided, with all matches starting at 15:30 BST unless otherwise noted.

The number of plastic bags used in England has increased by 200 million since 2013.  To combat this environmental problem, England will begin charging 5p for plastic bags in October.  This follows the lead of Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where charging for bags has resulted in a decrease in their use.  Campaigners hope the charge will encourage people to reuse bags and reduce the number of bags thrown away.

Strong winds across Wales caused damage to a school roof, power outages, train delays, and road closures. The winds also forced the cancellation of ferry services and the closure of some tourist attractions. While the winds eased into Friday evening, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of a Boxing Day event.

Michael B. Jordan will star in the upcoming Marvel film *Black Panther*, alongside Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. The film will be directed by Ryan Coogler, who also directed Jordan in *Creed*. *Black Panther* is set to be released in February 2018.

Alexandra Palace's east wing is undergoing a £26.6 million restoration project to transform it into a cultural destination. The project includes the restoration of the theatre, which will be used for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing £18.8 million, Haringey Council is contributing £6.8 million, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust is committed to raising the final £1 million by summer 2017. The theatre, which has been unused for decades, still has much of its original decor and stage machinery.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after 61 caps for England. He was a member of two World Cup and two European Championship squads, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova in 2014.

A fire destroyed the Smith family's home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove, and the family was able to escape thanks to the quick actions of their son David, who was on FaceTime with his father and saw the flames. The family lost their pets in the fire, but the community has rallied to support them with donations of clothes, shoes, and even a bike for David.

Energy drink giant, Red Bull, is considering a £200m offer for West Ham, a Premier League club. Sullivan and Gold, who own over 85% of the club, bought a majority stake in 2010 for £105m. Since August, West Ham has been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan has stated that a minority shareholding could be sold to clear debts, but he and Gold intend to pass ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards were held in Los Angeles, where "The Fault in Our Stars" won best movie and Shailene Woodley won best female performance. Other winners included Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, and Kevin Hart. The ceremony also featured promotional clips for upcoming films, including "Pitch Perfect 2," "Trainwreck," and "Ultron."

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old forward on loan from Aberdeen, has joined St Mirren. Smith has scored five goals for Dundee United this season and has made 89 appearances for Aberdeen. St Mirren manager Jack Ross believes Smith will be a good addition to the team and will provide another attacking option.

Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to repair 145 potholes per day for the next four months. The council will also have extra staff repairing drainage systems and clearing debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework on EnQuest's Thistle platform. The exposure was less than 1% of the level reportable to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but EnQuest notified the HSE. EnQuest and Wood Group both stated that they are committed to employee safety and have taken additional precautionary steps to prevent future exposure. The workers, however, are concerned about potential long-term health effects and are undergoing blood tests. The Unite union believes the workers have been poorly treated and that there should be more transparency about safety incidents. The HSE was notified of the incident but did not investigate because it was not reportable under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore is returning a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after it was determined that the sculpture was likely stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. The sculpture was purchased from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007, but the company's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The ACM is taking legal action to recover the $650,000 they paid for the sculpture.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km. The tremor was felt as far away as Milan and Florence, causing buildings to shake and people to evacuate into the streets. While there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage, phone lines and power supplies were cut in the Garfagnana area. Schools were evacuated as a precaution and checked for damage. The earthquake was described as a "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" tremor, typical for the area. This is the latest in a series of earthquakes in the region, including a magnitude-6 earthquake in May that caused significant damage and resulted in over 20 deaths.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a banana plant in South Yorkshire, despite initial doubts about the climate's suitability. The banana is still attached to the plant and not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of Grand Theft Auto V until March 24th, citing the need for additional testing and polishing. The company has also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release date. The PC version will feature 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum specifications for running the game on PC have also been released.

At 76 years old, artist David Simpson won the John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)". The painting depicts a leper squint, a hole in medieval churches that allowed undesirables to view services. Simpson has been shortlisted for the prize before and has been on the longlist three times. The prize money will be used to purchase art supplies. The John Moores Painting Prize is one of Britain's oldest art awards, established in 1957.

The offices of two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, were attacked early Thursday morning. Four masked assailants attacked the Yeni Safak building, causing a fire that was quickly extinguished by firefighters. Windows were shattered by gunfire at both buildings, which are located 20km apart. Police are investigating the attacks and searching for the assailants. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join the Mariners on a free transfer on January 1st. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. This is the first signing for the Mariners under manager Marcus Bignot.

Arsene Wenger, manager of Arsenal, commented on the recent appointment of Gareth Southgate as England's interim manager. Wenger believes Southgate is a good observer of the national team and has accumulated valuable experience. Wenger also stated that he is focused on his job at Arsenal and is not interested in the England manager position. Wenger also commented on the contract status of Arsenal players Hector Bellerin and Aaron Ramsey. Bellerin, who has been linked with a move to Barcelona or Manchester City, will be offered a new contract by Arsenal. Ramsey, who is recovering from a hamstring injury, will miss one or two more games.

A man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are investigating the incident with the Health and Safety Executive, and Fruehauf is cooperating fully.

The Scottish government has reached an agreement with Serco Northlink to end a dispute over the pay of seafarers on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles. The new charter arrangement will see contracted out services return to Serco Northlink, ensuring that all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

Jamie Mitchell was found guilty of manslaughter after he intervened in an argument between his mother and her boyfriend, Ken Dickie, who later died. Mitchell admitted to assaulting Dickie during the fight and later lied to police about the events, attempting to pervert the course of justice. Mitchell and his mother will be sentenced on February 6th.

Rod Temperton, a British songwriter known for his work with Michael Jackson and Heatwave, died at the age of 66 after a battle with cancer. Temperton, nicknamed "The Invisible Man" for his low profile, was born in Cleethorpes, England. He began writing songs after listening to Radio Luxembourg as a child. After working in a frozen food factory, he joined the disco group Heatwave, writing hits like "Boogie Nights," "Always & Forever," and "Groove Line." Temperton's work caught the attention of producer Quincy Jones, who hired him to write songs for Michael Jackson's "Off the Wall" and "Thriller" albums. Temperton won a Grammy Award in 1990 for his work on "Birdland" and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986 for his work on the soundtrack for "The Color Purple."

A team of researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading, and Brazil discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or geoglyphs, in the western Brazilian Amazon. These structures, possibly 2,000 years old, are thought to have been used sporadically for ritual gatherings, similar to Stonehenge or Mayan pyramids. The researchers found evidence that the surrounding vegetation was manipulated by humans, suggesting a form of "prehistoric supermarket" where valuable trees were concentrated. This discovery challenges the previous assumption that the Amazonian forests were untouched by humans before European arrival.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey in straight sets at the Shanghai Masters. Kyrgios, who won the Japan Open on Sunday, said he was tired from traveling and attributed his quiet demeanor on the court to fatigue. He also mentioned that the long ride to the courts was not ideal. Last year, Kyrgios was fined for an outburst at the Shanghai Masters, calling the tournament a "circus."

The HPV vaccine, currently given to girls aged 12-13 to prevent cervical cancer, is being advocated for by scientists and charities to also protect against head and neck cancers. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision on expanding the vaccination program to include boys.  The number of head and neck cancer cases is increasing, with a higher percentage of men being affected.  The HPV vaccine is seen as a preventative measure to combat this trend.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy from West Calder, Scotland, passed away after a battle with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He was diagnosed last August and documented his journey on social media, garnering over 28,000 followers. Despite his illness, Jak maintained a positive attitude and enjoyed visits from athletes and celebrities. In January, doctors informed Jak that his cancer had spread and that further treatment was not an option. He continued to fight the pain and his family encouraged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a match that saw few chances for either side.  Egypt's El Said scored the winning goal in the 89th minute, assisted by Salah. Uganda had a goal disallowed for offside in the first half. The win means Egypt will play Ghana on Wednesday to determine the top spot in Group D, while Uganda is out of the tournament.

Lancashire County Council has chosen the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College as the preferred location for a new railway station in Skelmersdale. The decision was made after a comparative study by Network Rail and the site is large enough to allow for future expansion. The council plans to acquire the land and work with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour.
Police discovered a large-scale marijuana grow operation in a warehouse near Ashbourne and arrested a man in his late 40s.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found injured in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German man of Kurdish origin from nearby Bad Muender, turned himself in to authorities. The woman underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. The motive for the attack is still under investigation.

A study of 4,600 Australian workers found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The study debunked the theory that women are reluctant to ask for more money, finding no evidence to support this claim.  The study found that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked, even when comparing like-for-like male and female workers. The researchers believe this difference is due to discrimination against women. The study also found that women and men under 40 are negotiating pay and conditions at the same rate, suggesting that negotiating behavior may be changing.

Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but has not found a suitable location. The two remaining cemeteries are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council has investigated many sites, but they have all been discounted due to factors such as size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, will feature an augmented reality app that allows visitors to access online information from signs and posters on the festival grounds. The app will provide videos, band interviews, and other content, allowing people to experience the festival remotely.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed that the horse suffered from a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". While Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, he had never collapsed before and showed no symptoms of post-race ataxia on Saturday. The horse had no significant underlying health issues, but had received treatment for a tendency to overheat in the past.

Davina Ayrton, 34, was found guilty of raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004. The victim said she shouted at Ayrton to stop the attack, but her friends did not wake up. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, attempted suicide last summer. She will be sentenced on March 4th and will be held at a male prison in Winchester.

The Serbian tennis duo of Novak Djokovic and Nenad Zimonjic lost their doubles match at the Rio Olympics to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares. This loss came after Djokovic was defeated in the singles competition by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world's number one tennis player, had previously lost in the third round of Wimbledon to American Sam Querrey. He later won his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

The annual chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Scotland, will feature over 20 competitors from various countries. The competitors will use only chainsaws to carve logs into animal and human shapes. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will be returning to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, a Welsh rugby player, is recovering from a foot injury sustained in September and is aiming to return to play in February. He has renewed his contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other teams to stay with his home region. Webb is aiming to be fit for the Six Nations tournament, which begins on February 7th.

Two men were arrested by US border agents for attempting to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada to San Francisco. One of the men fired a weapon at the agents and fled, but was later apprehended. A Canadian citizen, Nathan Hall, was arrested in British Columbia. Two other individuals, Kali Henifin and Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their alleged involvement in the smuggling operation. The three defendants in US custody face conspiracy as well as drug possession and distribution charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service has seen a significant increase in the number of children seeking help for online abuse, with over 4,500 children counseled in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity warns that online trolls cause misery and humiliation for thousands of children, and that cyberbullying can follow children home, making it difficult to escape. Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen urges adults, parents, and teachers to intervene to protect children from online bullying, as it often gets worse if left unchecked. The report is being released at the start of Anti-Bullying Week, during which the Anti Bullying Alliance will work with parents, schools, and other organizations to combat the problem.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem. This angered Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who accused the US of helping draft the resolution. The resolution passed, stating that settlements are illegal under international law and an obstacle to peace. Israel responded by summoning ambassadors, recalling its own ambassadors, and cancelling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing new homes in settlements to avoid further straining relations with the US ahead of Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas said the resolution paves the way for a peace conference in France.

The Queen celebrated her 90th birthday with a series of events, including a visit to the Royal Mail delivery office in Windsor, a ceremony to open a new bandstand, and a walk around Windsor to unveil a plaque marking The Queen's Walkway. Prince William, in a BBC interview, praised the Queen as a "guiding example" of a good monarch and said he takes his royal duties seriously but is not yet fully engaged with them. Ten stamps were released to celebrate the Queen's birthday, including a stamp sheet featuring four generations of the Royal Family. The Queen will also light a beacon on Thursday evening, setting in train a series of more than 900 beacons across the UK and around the world. On Friday, US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama will join the Queen for lunch at Windsor Castle.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew scored two quick goals in the first half to give West Ham the lead. Cheltenham had a few chances to score, but ultimately could not get past West Ham goalkeeper Adrian. West Ham made seven changes to their lineup after losing to Manchester United and Southampton in the Premier League.

Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old German man, was fined £1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years after pleading guilty to causing the death of motorcyclist Aidan McNicholl by careless driving. Werner failed to see McNicholl when turning right, causing a fatal collision. The victim's family did not want Werner to be sent to jail, accepting that the crash was a momentary lapse.
