Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, traveled to Syria and joined the Rayat al Tawheed group, which is affiliated with the Islamic State. He was involved in propaganda videos and appeals for donations. Khawaja was considered dangerous by British authorities and was tracked by MI5. He faked his own death and attempted to return to the UK, but was apprehended by police. He is facing a possible life sentence for his role in the Syrian conflict.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old forward, has signed with Barnsley for next season. Jackson scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, turning down a contract offer from them to join Barnsley. He is Barnsley's third signing for next season.

A container of Vanish laundry detergent bottles was lost overboard from a ship near Land's End in May. The bottles have been washing up on beaches in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove, Gunwalloe, Polurrian, Church Cove, and Marazion. The National Trust is clearing the bottles from the beaches as they pose a risk to wildlife. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency has not confirmed that the bottles are from the lost container, but the National Trust believes that is the case. Cornwall Wildlife Trust is concerned about the impact of the detergent on marine life. Cornwall Council is monitoring the beaches and advising the public to keep children and dogs away from the bottles.

A car crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at approximately 2:00 PM. Several people sustained minor injuries, and the road was closed with diversions in place via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is currently investigating the incident.

Dorian Dervite, a French center-back, signed a new contract with Bolton Wanderers after helping them secure promotion to the Championship. Dervite, who joined Bolton in 2014, made 14 appearances last season and was praised by manager Phil Parkinson for his contributions.

The Liberal Democrats and Labour have worked together in the House of Lords to defeat the government on issues such as EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. However, their alliance has broken down over the issue of Brexit, with the Lib Dems pushing for amendments to the Brexit deal and Labour deferring to the House of Commons. The Lib Dems accuse Labour of "waving through the government's plans" and "lining up with the Conservatives as they drive forward with a hard Brexit," while Labour accuses the Lib Dems of "grandstanding" and "building up false hope." Despite this recent disagreement, both parties have a history of working together on other issues, and the Lib Dems are open to future collaboration. However, a Labour source predicts "residual tensions" and doubts that the two parties will be able to work together in the future.

The UK is facing a difficult decision regarding its defense spending. While the world is becoming more dangerous, the UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces. The UK's military capabilities have been reduced, and the country is falling behind in defense spending compared to other nations. The next government will likely have to make further cuts, with the Ministry of Defence facing a potential loss of £2bn-£3bn from its annual budget. The issue of Trident, the UK's nuclear deterrent, is also up for debate, with different parties having varying stances on its future. The UK's two new aircraft carriers, while impressive, may be undermanned and under-equipped, raising concerns about their effectiveness.

Barcelona paid £48.6 million for Neymar, but the total cost of the player, including signing-on fees, wages, agents fees, and taxes, is £106.8 million. Barcelona has been accused of misappropriating funds in the transfer, and a judge in Spain has ruled that there is enough evidence to continue the investigation. Barcelona has made a tax payment of €13,550,830.56 to cover any potential tax discrepancies, but denies any wrongdoing.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father, was killed in a car crash when a car driven the wrong way on the motorway hit the van he was riding in. The driver of the other car, Albert Kenneth Newman, also died. Luciw's family and the driver of the van, Andy Harrington, believe that older drivers should be required to undergo regular driving tests and medical examinations to ensure their safety on the road. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) maintains that there is no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause accidents than other drivers and that they have no plans to restrict licensing based on age. Age UK believes that it is vital that older people are supported to continue driving safely for as long as possible.

The Scottish government has commissioned an independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, which are used to treat incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse. The review concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse and recommended that patients be offered a range of treatments and given the information to make informed choices. The report also said reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. The review was controversial, with two patients quitting the review group in protest at what they said was a watered-down report. The health secretary confirmed that the recommendations would continue to be implemented despite calls from campaigners for an all-out ban.

Laura Muir broke Liz McColgan's 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds, running 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan initially questioned whether the race met all the criteria for a record-breaking attempt, as Muir was the only competitor running the 5,000m distance. However, British Athletics confirmed that Muir's time is expected to be ratified as an official record. McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals and that her time is not her fastest. McColgan also noted the similarity between Muir's race and her own record-breaking race 25 years ago, where she also ran alone and lapped other runners.

The passage describes the results of the Olympic equestrian event, where Germany's Michael Jung won gold aboard Sam. France's Astier Nicolas took silver and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. Great Britain's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase. Fox-Pitt's medal bid was ruined by a disappointing performance in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth.

Andy Murray won his third round Wimbledon match against Fabio Fognini in four sets, 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. Murray will play Benoit Paire in the fourth round on Monday. Murray was happy to win in four sets, as the match was tense and he did not feel he played his best tennis. Fognini played well in the second set, but Murray was able to win the third and fourth sets to secure the victory.

Joe's Bar in Dungiven was closed for three months after being found to have served alcohol past closing hours. The bar's license holder, Colleen O'Neill, was fined £3,000 and James Thomas was fined £1,000 for allowing the consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. The judge stated that the bar had an "appalling record" and had not been run in a proper manner.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionist Party, launched his party's manifesto, "Real Partnership," which calls for action on issues such as tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, and standing up for the LGBT community. Nesbitt believes the election should be a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the DUP and Sinn FÃ©in's handling of it. He also stated that he would prefer to work with the SDLP rather than Sinn FÃ©in if the Ulster Unionists were to enter Stormont Castle. Nesbitt's comments about transferring to the SDLP have caused controversy, but he maintains that he would not withdraw any of his statements.

Northern Ireland will be aligning with England and Wales by passing a motion to pardon men convicted of now-abolished sexual offenses. This motion, dubbed "Turing's Law," will allow for both posthumous pardons and pardons for living men convicted of such offenses. The motion will be presented to the assembly for approval.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, broke the Scottish 1500m record with a time of 4:19.12, placing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This time surpasses Yvonne Murray's 1994 record of 4:22.60 and places Muir second on the British all-time list. Muir is pleased with her performance and hopes to secure a spot on the Great Britain Olympic team in Rio. She is currently training for the British trials in Birmingham from June 24-26.
The passage lists pictures of 26 beaches in Scotland that have been ranked as having the "most excellent" water quality.

The inquiry into the death of Alexander Litvinenko concluded that the Russian state was likely responsible for his murder. Litvinenko, a former Russian intelligence officer, was poisoned with polonium-210 in 2006 after meeting with two suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi. The inquiry found that the suspects left a trail of polonium behind them and had no credible explanation for the scientific evidence against them. While the Met Police wanted to try the suspects for murder, this is unlikely to happen as they remain in Russia and extradition attempts have failed.

Steve Smith, 26, has been named the new captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing Michael Clarke who has retired. Smith has previously captained the team in three Tests against India and is considered a talented player. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, refused to answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, but stated he is passionate about LGBT+ rights and will defend equal marriage. He also wants to extend marital rights for transgender people. Farron voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 because of concerns about "protection of individual liberties," but did not specify what those concerns were.

Accord Healthcare is taking over the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015. The company hopes to hire many of the former Sanofi employees, and the investment is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy.

Three senior staff members are leaving Aberdeen City Council: Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland. Ellis is leaving at the end of his contract, while Monaghan and Sutherland are taking voluntary redundancy and early retirement. The leader of the opposition SNP group, Stephen Flynn, believes these departures are a sign of the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects more departures in the future.

After crashing at the TT, rider Martin announced he was quitting road racing, but later clarified that he was only quitting racing on Hondas this year. He will not race at the North West 200 or the Ulster Grand Prix due to mechanical issues with the Fireblade bike and a crash by his teammate. He plans to race classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). This is the PDP's first loss in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, and they also lost control of Adamawa, a state heavily impacted by Boko Haram. The APC's victory is a historic gain, relegating the PDP to a regional party. The PDP's decline is attributed to voter dissatisfaction with their 16-year rule, including allegations of corruption and failure to address the Boko Haram insurgency. The APC's victory in Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub, is significant as it marks the first time the president's party has controlled the state since 1999. The PDP will need to rebuild under new leadership, while the APC faces challenges in managing oil-producing states where militant groups could disrupt production. Despite some violence, the elections were generally more peaceful than in previous years, suggesting a maturing democracy in Nigeria.

An environmental lobby group, Mighty, has accused agricultural commodities trader Olam of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to the haze caused by fires in Indonesia. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third party suppliers, denies the allegations and says it has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy. Mighty claims that Olam has created a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and has refused to release the names of its suppliers. Olam has since released the names of 14 suppliers and says it will remove any producers who do not comply with its sustainable principles. Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, has also denied the allegations, stating that it supports no-burn policies and does not direct the business operations of its portfolio companies. The report also highlights concerns in Gabon, where Olam is accused of "bulldozing rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations." Olam says its private-public partnerships in Gabon are both responsible and transparent.
A restaurant in the UK began serving "puppy platters" after a new law was passed allowing dogs to eat at restaurants, as long as they are outdoors.

Fernando Forestieri is questionable to play due to a knee injury. David Nugent may return from a groin injury after missing the last game. Jacob Butterfield is hoping to play after scoring a goal in the last game.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of the site. The ban was imposed in 2012 after the film Innocence of Muslims was uploaded to YouTube, sparking protests in Pakistan. The Pakistani government will be able to request the removal of content from YouTube, but Google has stated that these requests will not be automatically granted.

Musa Bility, head of the Liberian Football Association (LFA), is demanding that Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, step down from his position because he shares the same nationality as one of the presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. Bility argues that Scala's presence creates a conflict of interest, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations. Scala, however, maintains that there is no conflict of interest and that he only stepped down in the 2015 election because the Swiss candidate was the incumbent president. Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace Sepp Blatter as FIFA president will take place on February 26th.

Two men, Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56), were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road on Monday morning while working in a paint-spraying area. Police believe a flashover explosion, caused by a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, led to a fire-ball effect. The Health and Safety Executive is investigating the incident.

Tunisia and Morocco were both in danger of being banned from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations. Tunisia was threatened with expulsion after lodging complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) regarding a controversial penalty call in the 2015 tournament. Morocco was banned from the 2015 tournament after refusing to host it due to concerns about the Ebola virus. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) overturned the ban and reduced the fine imposed on Morocco. Both countries have since apologized to CAF and are now preparing to compete in the 2017 tournament.

Following a brawl in the 95th minute of the game, Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were both given red cards. Aguero was banned for four matches for violent conduct, while Fernandinho was banned for three. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face any further action.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the worst cancer survival rates in the developed world. A pilot program in Rhondda Cynon Taf and Neath Port Talbot will focus on patients whose GPs suspect may have cancer but show no urgent signs or symptoms. This comes after doctors visited Denmark to see their diagnostic systems. Health officials in Cwm Taf observed that the health service in Denmark had improved cancer survival rates. The concern is that a patient in Wales without clear symptoms waits too long for a diagnosis because they don't "fit easily" into any specific treatment pathway. This means GPs refer the patient back and forth for multiple tests, which can take weeks. As a result, there is a fear that too many patients begin treatment when their cancer has progressed or is incurable. Forty GPs in Rhondda Cynon Taf who believe something may be wrong can refer the patient to a diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days. It is estimated that about six patients per week will be seen and given various tests, hopefully on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with "worrying" symptoms are diagnosed in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors therefore want to reach the majority of

England won the second Test match against Pakistan by a large margin, leveling the series. Joe Root was named man of the match for his impressive performance, scoring 254 runs in the first innings and 71 in the second. England's bowlers also performed well, bowling Pakistan out for 234 in the second innings. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment with his team's performance, citing poor shot selection and a lack of confidence. The third Test match is scheduled to begin on August 3rd at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland is leading the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand and has named Rob Howley as part of his backroom team.  McBryde will be the head coach for the third time, having led Wales on tours in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour to assist McBryde. The WRU is in discussions with other individuals about the summer tour and hopes to confirm the full make-up of the management team next week. Union chairman Gareth Davies believes the involvement of Welsh coaches will benefit the national team.

Hull City defeated Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Southampton took an early lead with a penalty goal by Charlie Austin, but Hull came back with two goals in the second half. Robert Snodgrass, who came on as a substitute, scored the first goal and assisted on the second goal. Hull's goalkeeper, David Marshall, made several saves to preserve the win.

A fatal motorcycle crash occurred on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa at approximately 2:15 PM. The motorcyclist, a local resident, was killed, while the tractor driver was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police are requesting witnesses to come forward and have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction.

Macedonia's President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into claims of abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to "put an end to the agony" ahead of early elections in June. The move was condemned by the opposition and EU officials, who said it was illegal and put Macedonia's EU membership ambitions at risk. The crisis was sparked by covert recordings which appear to show ministers plotting vote-rigging and the cover-up of a murder.

Swansea City is looking for a new manager after firing Bob Bradley. Curtis and Paul Williams will manage the team for the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club wants to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the first choice. Curtis believes the team has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014 and that the team has not been able to adequately replace the players they have lost. He believes the current squad is good enough to stay up and reminds new players of the club's history and how important it is to stay in the Premier League.

Dagenham & Redbridge, who reached League One in 2010, were relegated to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient. Dagenham's manager, John Still, said his team lacked organization and discipline, which led to their defeat. Leyton Orient's interim manager, Andy Hessenthaler, said the team had to be professional and win games to make the playoffs.

Steven Gerrard, former captain of Liverpool, will return to the club in February as a youth coach. This will be his first job since retiring as a player in November after a 19-year career. Gerrard is working towards his Uefa A coaching licence and hopes to become a manager in the future.
Morton defeated Alloa 4-1. McManus scored two goals for Morton, while Forbes and Johnstone each scored one. McAusland scored the lone goal for Alloa.

Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three places in Birmingham which have now closed. The owners are being investigated under suspicion of running an illegal school. Ofsted and ministers are concerned that some places are taking advantage of the legal right to home educate to operate what are in fact illegal schools. The government has provided funding for a team of six inspectors whose job will be to investigate illegal schools. The education secretary has now said she intends to go further and has asked Ofsted to prepare cases for prosecution against unregistered schools it has identified.

Lilliard Gin, the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837, is located at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh. The gin is made with local botanicals and aims to capture the "terroir" of the region. The distillery is small, but the team hopes to make the Scottish Borders a "region of distilling excellence." The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545.

Gary Green, 51, was jailed for 16 months and two weeks for reversing a tractor into Harry Whitlam, killing him. Green was over twice the legal driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer before going to bed at 2:00 am. Green was prosecuted under health and safety legislation because the incident occurred on private land.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker, was banned from all football-related activities for biting Giorgio Chiellini during the 2014 World Cup. The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) upheld the ban but allowed Suarez to train and play in friendly matches. The CAS ruled that the ban on all football-related activities was excessive and that Suarez should be allowed to train to avoid a negative impact on his performance after the suspension. Suarez will still have to serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the UK's "World's Strongest Couple" competition by beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania. The competition involved a 380-meter course with obstacles such as haystacks, a steep slope, and water pistols. Blake-Smith and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government will be replacing the paper tax disc system with an electronic system in October 2014. This will allow people to pay the charge by monthly direct debit. The change will likely result in a reduction in the number of DVLA employees needed to process refunds, but the government plans to redeploy these workers to other areas of the business.

Hungary's government is facing pressure from the EU to change its laws regarding asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education. Hungary's foreign minister, Peter Szijjarto, stated that Hungary will not back down on these issues and that Poland will veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The EU objects to Hungary's laws because they are seen as interfering with the rights of asylum seekers and NGOs, and the higher education law could lead to the closure of the Central European University.

The live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast will be released on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, Dan Stevens will play the Beast, and Luke Evans will play Gaston. The film will also feature Kevin Kline as Maurice, Josh Gad as LeFou, and Emma Thompson as Mrs. Potts.  Bill Condon will direct the film, which will begin filming in May.

Adrian Gill, a well-known journalist for the Sunday Times, passed away after a battle with cancer. Gill was known for his witty and fearless writing style, and his columns often caused controversy. He was a controversialist but also a kind man and a brilliant writer. Gill began his writing career in the 1980s with art reviews for magazines, before writing for Tatler and then the Sunday Times. He was married twice and had four children.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked in Ulan Bator while performing. The Russian embassy, which is investigating the incident, claims reports of the attack are distorted. Amraa was wearing a traditional Mongolian robe with a swastika, which is a traditional symbol in Mongolia and not associated with Nazism. His father stated that Amraa was in a coma for 10 days after being beaten with a metal object. The suspect, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been arrested due to the severity of the injuries.

On Monday, members of Plane Stupid staged a protest on the northern runway of Heathrow Airport, opposing the airport's expansion plans. The protesters were charged with aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. They will appear in court on August 19th. The Metropolitan Police will review security at the airport.

Glamorgan's Nick Selman scored a century, his second in first-class cricket, to lead his team to a total of 220.  Gloucestershire struggled against the Glamorgan bowlers, with Matt Taylor and Craig Miles taking wickets at regular intervals.  Selman's century was a welcome return to form after a string of low scores.  Gloucestershire's innings was a question of survival in the evening gloom, with the day ending evenly balanced.  Glamorgan are being led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph, who has a neck problem.

Craig Hughes, 33, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he threatened to ambush police officers on the Dee Estuary. Hughes admitted to making two false reports to the police while intoxicated, with the intention of having officers come to the scene so he could shoot them. Hughes has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail awaiting trial for firearms offences at the time of the threats. He will be sentenced next week.

Surrey defeated Yorkshire in a T20 Blast match, winning by 19 runs. Surrey's Davies and Foakes put on a 130-run partnership, helping Surrey reach a score of 255-7. Yorkshire's run chase was hampered by a three-wicket burst from Stuart Meaker, who dismissed Bairstow, Ballance, and Leaning. Despite Bresnan's 68 runs, Yorkshire fell short of the target, finishing at 236 all out. Surrey captain Gareth Batty praised his team's performance, highlighting the crucial partnership between Davies and Foakes. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment, acknowledging that their bowlers were exceptional but their top five batsmen failed to make a significant contribution.

A 56ft trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 7:00 am BST reporting a pump failure that was unable to handle incoming water. The RNLI lifeboat crew towed the vessel to Holyhead after placing a pump on board.

Scottish runner Laura Muir will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games in Australia due to her veterinary medicine studies. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, will be completing her final year of university. She is hoping to compete in the World Indoor Championships in March and feels she has at least two more Olympics in her future.

Liverpool is a long way from repeating last season's title challenge. They are miles away from the level required to mount another title challenge and will have to improve and work hard just to get in the top four. Liverpool's problem is that they overachieved massively last season, which has raised expectations unrealistically. Rodgers has been questioned for his transfer market decisions, especially up front. Liverpool has lost a lot of goals from their line-up with the sale of Suarez and Sturridge's injury. Rodgers has not bought the right strikers to fit his system. Liverpool is not starting games with the same intensity they did last season, or pressing teams high up the pitch to force them into mistakes. Liverpool's defense was seen as their weakest link last season and, despite trying several different combinations, Rodgers did not get it right. Liverpool still looks all over the place at the back. Liverpool lacks a leader at the back and their goalkeeper does not give them much help there. Rodgers tried three at the back against Newcastle, but I cannot see him doing the same against Chelsea. Liverpool can still qualify for the knockout stages in Europe if they win their last two games in Group B. Rodgers has to decide who to play against Chelsea, but whoever he

East Ayrshire Council will build a new educational facility in Kilmarnock that will house primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare center. The council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was born and educated in Kilmarnock. McIlvanney was a prolific writer who gained recognition for his first novel, "Remedy Is None," and was known as the "Godfather of Tartan Noir." He wrote the acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other Glasgow-based works, as well as contributing to political and sporting life in Scotland.

A sea mine was discovered near Gourock, Scotland, prompting the evacuation of three streets and an exclusion zone on the river and at sea. The mine, believed to be British from the 1940s or 1950s, was deemed too unstable to be dealt with in place, so it was moved to a safer location. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and there was no immediate danger to the community.

UK Sport has announced funding for 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for the Tokyo 2020 Games, totaling £345 million. This is £2 million less than the record £347 million allocated for the Rio Games. The funding decisions were made based on medal potential, with the goal of achieving 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton, which won a bronze medal in Rio, is the only sport that had its funding removed, despite its success. Other sports, such as basketball, handball, and volleyball, have also had their funding withdrawn in recent years. UK Sport is still determining funding for the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020, including baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sports climbing, surfing, Para-taekwondo, and Para-badminton.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth will be demolished to make way for a new six-story, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development was approved by the council despite objections from English Heritage, who argued that the scale of the project would harm the conservation area. Supporters of the project, including the council, believe it will benefit tourism and provide improved living conditions for older residents.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a soldier in the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was found unconscious in Brecon, Wales, on May 8th. CCTV footage showed him being punched and beaten by Jake Vallely, who was later found guilty of manslaughter. Vallely had been drinking heavily and boasted about being the "hardest man in Brecon" before the attack. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of any involvement in the attack. The attack shocked the community of Brecon, and police urged people to avoid violence. Pte Boyd's family described him as a loving and caring person with a promising career ahead of him. They said Vallely had created a void in their family that will never be filled.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, resigned after a major error occurred during the local elections. Voters were turned away from polling stations because their names were not on the voter registration list. An independent investigation has been launched to determine the cause of the error and will conclude by the end of May.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2-1 in a match where both teams scored from free kicks in the first half. Gateshead's Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal in the second half, heading in a cross from Jamie Chandler. Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his team's second-half performance, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team's second-half play.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the social and economic well-being of their citizens over 60. Norway ranks highest, while Afghanistan and Mozambique rank lowest.

OneWeb is a project to create a network of at least 600, and potentially more than 2,000, satellites to provide broadband internet access to every corner of the globe, with a particular focus on providing internet access to schools. To achieve this, OneWeb and Airbus have created a new assembly line in Toulouse, France, with two more planned for Florida, that will produce satellites at a rate of three per shift for less than a million dollars each. The first 10 satellites are scheduled to launch in April 2019, with more to follow in November 2019. The project will require more than 20 Soyuz rockets to launch the satellites into orbit. OneWeb is not the only company planning a mega-constellation of satellites, but Airbus believes that OneWeb has a first-mover advantage. The project has already raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking loans to complete the rollout. OneWeb is registered in the UK's Channel Islands and will work with the UK Space Agency to ensure that the project complies with regulations. OneWeb is committed to debris mitigation and has pledged to de-orbit its satellites within two years.

The Scottish government will have £390 million more in spending available to them next year, according to the UK government. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 mean that its discretionary budget will be 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11. The Scottish government is determined to defend and protect the key priorities that the people of Scotland expect them to deliver on, such as schools, hospitals, and the police service. The UK government's Scotland Office said the Scottish government should focus more on gearing up for its new powers and getting the best for Scotland, rather than grievance.

Changing Places toilets are larger than standard accessible toilets and include features like a hoist and a bench to help people with severe disabilities use the facilities. Campaigners are calling for these toilets to be made compulsory in larger buildings like shopping centers, cinemas, and sports stadiums. Currently, they are only recommended in building regulations. The lack of these toilets can cause stress and isolation for families with disabled members, as they may have to change their loved ones in unsuitable locations.  While there are logistical and financial barriers to installing these toilets, some businesses have found ways to adapt existing facilities to include Changing Places toilets.

A group of Italian consumer organizations filed a formal complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald's of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees. The complaint alleges that McDonald's makes franchisees sign longer-than-average contracts, preventing them from switching to competitors, and leases premises at above market rates. The complaint claims that this leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores. The SEIU and European unions are supporting the complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate the charges. McDonald's maintains that it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees, and that this approach has been successful for many years. The European Commission will now study the submission and may launch an investigation if it believes the allegations are founded.

Thirteen-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh began on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church, where Josh's father is on the pastoral staff. The campaign has gone viral, with the hashtag being used by people all over the world. A mystery donor paid for a billboard with the hashtag to be erected at Holywood playing fields.

The British Ministry of Defence is restructuring its military estate, which includes closing Brecon Barracks in Wales. The closure has been met with opposition from local MP Chris Davies, who argues that the barracks has a long and distinguished history and that the closure will negatively impact the local economy. The Ministry of Defence is creating a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan, and closing Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024.

The UK fishing industry is facing uncertainty as the country prepares to leave the EU. The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report that examines the risks and opportunities for the industry. The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report also suggests that the UK should retain many elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) post-Brexit, including the use of scientific advice for setting quotas. However, many in the fishing industry believe that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, citing recent increases in allowable catches for certain fish species as evidence of a brighter future.

The US government has access to a vast amount of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. This access is facilitated by the Prism program, which allows the NSA to access the servers of major technology companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple. The US government has confirmed that it requested millions of phone records from Verizon, including call duration, location, and phone numbers. While the government claims these surveillance activities are necessary for national security, critics argue that they violate privacy rights and may be more intrusive than necessary. The US Patriot Act of 2001 granted American authorities new powers over European data stored in the US, raising concerns about the reach of US surveillance beyond its borders. The extent of other governments' involvement in Prism is unknown, but the EU has expressed concern about the program's impact on EU citizens.

OpenAI, a new non-profit research company, was founded with the goal of ensuring that artificial intelligence benefits humanity. The company, funded by prominent figures like Elon Musk and Peter Thiel, aims to conduct research free from financial obligations, focusing on the positive impact of AI. While some experts, including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, have expressed concerns about the potential dangers of AI, OpenAI emphasizes the importance of developing AI that serves humanity and is widely accessible.

Ben Parkinson, a British soldier who was seriously injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006, carried the Olympic torch on June 26th. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits friend associations to 5,000 per personal page. Parkinson's mother, Diane, said the responses to his torch carrying had been phenomenal and that Ben was really "buoyed up" by the support and friendship he had been shown. She said that Ben's Facebook page had received 19,000 hits on an update and that the family had received a lot of mail and emails. Facebook suggested that Parkinson consider having a page instead of a profile or use subscribe so that people can see his public updates without actually becoming a friend.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the United States remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. The median household income decreased by 1.5%, and the poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, increased for the first time since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance decreased to 15.7%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, signed a new contract with Lancashire that will keep him with the team until 2019. Buttler, who is known for his short-format expertise, has scored three of England's fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Lancashire's cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and his impact on the team, particularly in the T20 Blast final. Buttler, who has been playing in the Indian Premier League, will return to Lancashire for their T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates, HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, are currently docked in Portsmouth Harbour. The government's Disposal Services Authority is selling the ships, with bids due in late February and March. The government wants to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capabilities.  Penny Mordaunt, MP for Portsmouth North, supports this but also wants to see at least one frigate saved from the scrapyard, possibly as a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer.

Fiji has experienced significant political and racial tensions since 1987, leading to a series of coups and international isolation. These events have negatively impacted the economy, particularly tourism, and caused a decline in Fiji's international reputation. The country's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the former now making up a slight majority. Despite a diverse economy, Fiji has faced persistent trade and budget deficits, making it heavily reliant on foreign aid.

Syria missed the deadline to hand over its entire chemical weapons stockpile, but Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad claims two shipments were attacked by terrorists. He also denies the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, despite reports of civilian casualties. The Syrian government also denies rebel control of Aleppo's central prison, despite reports of the prison being seized by the Islamic Front coalition. The US is concerned about the slow pace of the chemical weapons removal process, while Russia has set a new deadline of March 1st for the transfer of weapons to the coast.

The 2014 Man Booker Prize shortlist includes six novels: *The Lives of Others* by Jhumpa Lahiri, *J* by Howard Jacobson, *How To Be Both* by Ali Smith, *To Rise Again at a Decent Hour* by Joshua Ferris, *We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves* by Karen Joy Fowler, and *The Narrow Road to the Deep North* by Richard Flanagan. The winner will be announced on Tuesday night at London's Guildhall. The prize is open to all authors writing in English, regardless of nationality. The shortlist includes three British writers, two Americans, and one Australian. The judging panel is chaired by AC Grayling and includes Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner.

A celebrity, referred to as PJS, is appealing a court ruling that lifted a ban on his name being published in the media. The Supreme Court will hear arguments about whether to grant the appeal and if so, whether to allow or dismiss it. The man, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, is seeking to protect his privacy from allegations of extramarital affairs published by The Sun on Sunday. The court ruled that the ban should be lifted because the story has already been widely published in other countries and online, making it impossible to maintain confidentiality.

Fosse Park, a shopping center near junction 21 of the M1, was recently purchased for Â£345.5m. The new owners plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. They see the shopping center as an investment opportunity and want to improve the overall look and feel of the area, particularly the common areas and facilities.

The release of the live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" in Malaysia was delayed after the film was flagged for a "gay moment" featuring LeFou, Gaston's sidekick. The Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) approved the film with a minor edit to the "gay moment" but the release date has yet to be announced. The decision to review the film sparked criticism from many who felt it was unnecessary and hypocritical.

Southampton City Council estimates that there are 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, despite the fact that landlords who rent to more than three unrelated people are required to apply for a license. The council has prosecuted one firm and 13 individuals for not obtaining a license, which can cost up to £1,000. Shelter helpline adviser Nadeem Khan said that tenants in HMOs often fear eviction and living in poorly maintained properties.

Following the Irish election, Fine Gael and Fianna Fáil are attempting to form a minority government.  Fianna Fáil will not support a program for government, but will facilitate a minority government.  The main sticking point is water charges, with Fianna Fáil wanting their immediate removal and Fine Gael seeing a role for them.  A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being considered.  No party was able to form a majority government, and a taoiseach has not been elected.

A fire broke out on the car deck of the Sorrento ferry, which was traveling to Valencia from Mallorca. The fire quickly spread, forcing the evacuation of all passengers and crew onto lifeboats. Three people were injured, one seriously, and were transported to a hospital by helicopter. The fire was so intense that the ferry may sink. The passengers were rescued by other ships and are expected to arrive in Palma de Mallorca within a few hours. Psychologists will be at the port to provide counseling.

The Electoral Commission found that 38 MPs reported cases of people, including students, claiming to have voted twice in the 8 June election. The Commission recommended that electoral registers be better connected to identify duplicate entries. The Commission also stated that the online registration system should include a verification function to prevent duplicate applications. The Commission found that the number of duplicate applications was significant, with estimates ranging from 30% to 70% in different areas. The Commission also stated that voting twice in a general election is a criminal offense punishable by an unlimited fine. Labour warned against making it harder for young people to register to vote, arguing that a blanket ban on being registered at two addresses would exclude those who need to be registered in two places for work or study.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, was found dead in his prison cell. Phillips had a troubled past, including multiple legal issues and convictions for assault. He was recently accused of killing his former cellmate and was awaiting trial. Phillips' former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as intelligent but struggling with anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official soldier in the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour". He is the 30th mascot ram in the regiment's history, dating back to the Indian Mutiny War. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in 2014 and has participated in various events, including switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling Europa League quarterfinal match. The victory was a testament to manager Jurgen Klopp's ability to inspire his players and turn doubters into believers. Liverpool's comeback from a 2-0 deficit was reminiscent of their 2005 Champions League final victory over AC Milan. Klopp's influence on the team was evident in their determination and refusal to give up. The match was a testament to the power of belief and the importance of a strong team spirit.

The UK government met with representatives from Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to discuss Brexit negotiations. The UK government plans to hold monthly meetings to share information and allow the devolved administrations to voice their views. The Scottish government wants more transparency from the UK government about its plans, including whether it intends to remain in the single market or the customs union. The Scottish government will oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court during the appeal of the High Court judgment on how Article 50 will be triggered.

The University of Nottingham is studying 13 cloned sheep, including four clones of Dolly the sheep, to determine if cloning affects aging and health. The study focuses on the three co-morbidities most associated with aging: cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The researchers are comparing the cloned sheep to a wider population of sheep to see if they are any different in terms of these co-morbidities. The results of the study, which could have profound implications for the future of cloning, will be published next week.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes at York. She will now go to Chantilly for the French Oaks, while Gosden will rely on Enable and Coronet for the Epsom Oaks. Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and will decide whether he runs after walking the course.

The British pound has been fluctuating against the dollar and euro, with investors becoming increasingly uncertain about the outcome of the upcoming referendum on the UK's membership in the EU. The Leave campaign has argued that the pound's recent decline is simply a return to March levels, while analysts predict further volatility in the currency as the referendum approaches. The potential economic impact of leaving the EU has also caused a decline in Asian stock markets, with the FTSE 100 index in London also experiencing a drop.

Braintree Town, a part-time team, lost to Barrow, extending their losing streak to three games. Despite the loss, manager Cowley remains optimistic about his team's performance, noting their remarkable season so far. He acknowledges the challenges of being a part-time team and the difficulty of their current position, but remains positive about their future.

In April 2015, Northern Ireland will transfer planning decision-making power from the Planning Service to local councils. This move is seen as a positive step towards a more democratic planning system, allowing councils to develop their own community and development plans. However, concerns exist about the potential for discrimination and corruption, as seen in the 1960s. The environmental group Friends of the Earth advocates for a strict code of conduct and increased transparency in political donations to ensure fairness and prevent favoritism towards certain communities.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times by an air gun in Winchburgh, Scotland. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, found her injured and took her to the Scottish SPCA. Teenie's back leg had to be amputated, and she is now learning to walk again. The Scottish SPCA is urging the Scottish government to implement air gun licensing, as they believe it would help prevent future incidents like this. However, a majority of respondents to the government's consultation on air gun licensing opposed the plan.

Liverpool signed Belgian international Christian Benteke to a long-term contract, making him the club's second most expensive signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa, was brought in to help revive Liverpool's attack after a disappointing season in which they struggled to score goals. Benteke is Liverpool's seventh summer signing and joins other new forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino, and Divock Origi.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that while tablet computers are increasingly common in schools, there is no clear evidence that they improve academic performance. The study, which looked at 671 schools, found that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablets, with 9% of schools providing a tablet for every student. While head teachers reported positive impacts, such as increased motivation and family involvement, researchers could not isolate the impact of technology on academic achievement. The study also found that young people are heavily immersed in technology, with many taking internet-connected devices to bed for social media and other activities.

The Museum of Liverpool is hosting an exhibition called "Growing Up in the City" which features 25 photographs that capture the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, showcases how childhood has changed over the years, including the shift from children working to children playing. The exhibition is on display until September 25th.

Barrow centre-back Anderson, 27, has joined Torquay United, while striker Keating, 21, has also joined the club. Anderson has played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy, while Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Torquay manager Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as hungry to prove himself. Torquay is currently four points above the relegation zone.

Bolivia has passed a new law that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent. The law also sets a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law was passed to address the needs of Bolivia, one of the poorest countries in South America, where over 500,000 children work to supplement their family income. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) is studying the legislation to determine if it violates international regulations on child labor.

Rosie O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress, recently suffered a heart attack. She experienced chest pain, nausea, and fever after helping a woman in her home. O'Donnell researched her symptoms online and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. She described her heart attack as a "widow maker" and warned her readers to be aware of heart attack symptoms and to call 911 immediately.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a 16-year-old boy from Harrow, was stabbed and killed in an alleyway in Kenton, London, after a party. Police believe he was not involved in an earlier altercation with a group of youths who were denied entry to the party, but was targeted later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16. A third boy, aged 14, was arrested on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark has implemented a new system for diagnosing cancer patients, which has resulted in improved survival rates. The system has three routes: a fast-track diagnosis and treatment route for patients with "alarm" symptoms, diagnosis centers for patients with symptoms that GPs cannot diagnose, and "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms. The system has led to better organization of how patients are diagnosed within existing resources and has helped to break down barriers between GPs and specialists.

Powys County Council will take over the role of regulating estate agents in Wales, issuing warnings and banning orders against agents who act dishonestly or break estate agent laws. The council will receive £170,000 a year to carry out the work, which was previously done by the OFT. People with complaints about estate agents will still contact their local authority trading standards department, who will refer cases to Powys if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached.

The Nuffield Trust has recommended that the NHS reshape its workforce to better utilize the skills of its 1.3 million employees. The report highlights examples of nurses filling in for doctors and pharmacists, which the report argues is beneficial due to the changing nature of healthcare. The report also acknowledges that funding will be needed to implement these changes. While some support the idea, others warn against using it as a quick fix for staffing shortages and emphasize the importance of proper training for doctors.

A crash occurred on Lower Bristol Road in Bath at 3:00 GMT, causing the road to be closed until 2:00 PM. The closure caused delays for commuters and bus services during rush hour. First bus services have resumed, but it will take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

The Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimates that the Swansea tidal lagoon project will result in the death of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout each year, while Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputes these figures, claiming they have no scientific basis. TLP claims that the NRW refused to share its methodology for calculating these figures and that its own computer modeling estimates a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species being killed. The NRW maintains that its figures are based on the best available evidence and have been assessed by independent experts.

Northern Ireland is establishing a new agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to help the industry work together and improve marketing efforts. The new body will be led by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will provide strategic direction for both government and private sector organizations. The move was announced by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster, who said the agri-food industry is "hugely important" to Northern Ireland, employing almost 100,000 people.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday. The event is part of a larger project to plant millions of trees across the UK in honor of those who died in World War I. The trust plans to plant 40,000 trees at Brackfield Wood in tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who died in the war. The public is invited to participate in the planting and the trust is providing saplings and advising volunteers to wear appropriate footwear.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence and honor crimes. The book was praised for its strong writing and plot. Sara Paretsky, creator of detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career writing about the female private investigator. Paretsky was recognized for her groundbreaking work in creating a strong female protagonist and for her support of female crime writers through the organization Sisters In Crime.

Mitch Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, will rejoin the Worcestershire Rapids after June's ICC Trophy. Santner, who broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, is looking forward to making up for lost time and making an impact with bat and ball. Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in a hit-and-run accident in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was 19 years younger than him and had met him online in 2006. The coroner ruled that Pring was unlawfully killed, citing evidence that the car involved had stolen license plates and did not brake or stop. Pring's family believes that Ziuzina was involved in his death to inherit his money and property. They point to her attempts to claim his assets shortly after his death, her affair with a Ukrainian man, and her lack of cooperation with the inquest. The Ukrainian police initially closed the case but reopened it in 2011 as a murder inquiry. The case is still active but not actively pursued.

Charlie, a young boy from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle Children's Hospital for experimental T-Cell Therapy treatment after his first transplant failed. His family was overwhelmed when an anonymous donor paid for the treatment, which is unavailable in the UK. Charlie's parents are grateful for the donation and are expecting to receive a treatment start date next week.

Apple has implemented a new security measure to prevent third-party software from accessing iCloud data. This measure, called two-factor authentication, requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering their username and password on an unfamiliar device. While this measure is optional, security experts recommend that it be made the default setting. The new security measure prevents software like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker from accessing iCloud backups, which was previously possible even with two-factor authentication enabled. However, concerns remain about the security of the recovery key, which can be lost or stolen, potentially allowing unauthorized access to iCloud data.

Former "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" contestant, Mark Wright, is in talks to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town Football Club. The 30-year-old would also become a club director. The club is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and is owned by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who recently invested £10,000 a week in the club.

The Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee has invited Sports Direct owner Mike Ashley to a public meeting to discuss the treatment of low-paid workers at the company's warehouse. The committee has offered several dates for the meeting, but Mr. Ashley has not agreed to attend any of them. If he does not agree to attend, the committee may seek the support of the House of Commons to compel his attendance.

The report, "Putin. War," was compiled by Ilya Yashin and colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov. The report details the human and economic costs of the conflict in Ukraine, accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war for his own benefit. The report presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being used in the conflict, including testimonies from volunteer soldiers who admit to being directed by Russian generals. The report also calculates the cost of the conflict to Russia at 53 billion roubles. The report's authors believe that Putin orchestrated the war to boost his popularity, which they believe was successful.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire. The 34-year-old died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield in connection with his death.

The UK government has published a letter to the EU regarding Brexit, but the Welsh government was not consulted on its drafting. The Welsh First Minister, Carwyn Jones, has expressed his disappointment with this lack of consultation, stating that the devolved administrations have been treated with a lack of respect. The UK government has stated that it will consult with the devolved administrations on which powers should be devolved to them, but the specific powers and funding have not been determined.

Two cars were damaged in an attack on police officers in Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the attack, calling it "mindless." The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that the officers were attacked while "carrying out duties" and appealed to parents to know their children's whereabouts.

American Apparel's board of directors filed court documents detailing evidence of illicit emails and racially derogatory taunts written by former CEO Dov Charney to female employees. These documents were filed in response to Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. The board stated that they do not expect Charney to return to the company, citing his violation of the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy.

Great Britain's men's basketball team will play Greece at the Copper Box in London on July 1, 2017. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. This is Britain's only home game before they compete at FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts in September.

The iPhone's launch in 2007 marked a significant turning point in mobile technology, transforming the way people interact with the world. The author, a BBC journalist, witnessed the launch firsthand and was initially skeptical about the iPhone's revolutionary potential. However, the author now recognizes the iPhone's impact, acknowledging its role in making powerful computers accessible to billions and disrupting various industries, including photography. The author highlights the iPhone's user-friendly interface as a key factor in its success, contrasting it with earlier mobile devices that lacked intuitive design. The author concludes that the iPhone's launch in San Francisco marked the beginning of the mobile connected era, paving the way for future innovations in artificial intelligence by companies like Amazon and Google.

Seven cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire have died in the last two weeks after ingesting antifreeze. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate. The charity is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially antifreeze, as it is the time of year when people use it in their cars.

Despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement austerity measures, Greece is experiencing a surge in tourism. The author questions why Greeks are not protesting against the painful economic measures, suggesting that the public may be waiting to see the full extent of the concessions made by Alexis Tsipras in exchange for a new bailout. The author notes that Tsipras remains popular despite failing to deliver on his promises to end austerity. The author argues that the new bailout will only be successful if it offers hope for a better future and that creditors should ease the burden of Greece's debt to facilitate genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp will return to EastEnders to play Grant Mitchell for a brief period in order to reunite the Mitchell family for the final time before Peggy Mitchell's death.  Kemp's character will return to Walford to say goodbye to his mother and be reunited with his brother Phil.

Alice Ruggles was murdered by Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon, who had become obsessed with her and stalked her.  Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, knew it was Dhillon who had killed their daughter as soon as the police told them she was dead.  Dhillon was found guilty of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.  Alice's parents have set up the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of the dangers of stalking.

The UK government has delayed a final decision on the £18 billion Hinkley Point nuclear power plant project, despite EDF's approval of the funding. The government's decision came after EDF's board voted to approve the project, and the timing seemed calculated to cause maximum impact. The delay has been met with criticism from industry leaders who are concerned about the impact on energy supplies and the potential for higher energy costs. Environmentalists are also concerned about the project, citing potential environmental damage and the high cost of the project. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement.

A new divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person the spouse committed adultery with. Family lawyers are concerned that this will increase conflict and complexity in divorce cases. While the form states that it is not normally necessary to name the person, lawyers believe that people are likely to fill in the space. Naming the person involved in the adultery will make them part of the court case, requiring them to be sent paperwork and given a chance to respond. This could lead to delays and increased costs.  Despite the form's guidance, many people want to involve the new partner in the proceedings, which judges generally disapprove of.

The Welsh government is trying to balance environmental, economic, and social concerns in its forestry development. While the government encourages the planting of native, broadleaf trees and better access for recreation, the timber industry is struggling to meet its needs due to a loss of commercial forest land. The timber industry is worth over £450 million to the Welsh economy, but the current system is too bureaucratic and the emphasis on environmental aspects is hindering the growth of commercial forestry.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck by a vehicle in Coatbridge, Scotland. The incident occurred near Langloan Primary School on Bank Street at approximately 4:40 PM. The boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

The Arctic Convoys were a series of maritime missions that resupplied the Soviet Union during World War II. The convoys faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe weather conditions. The Russian Embassy awarded the Ushakov medal to the veterans of the Arctic Convoys as a symbol of gratitude for their service. The Foreign Office initially blocked the award due to rules prohibiting British soldiers from receiving foreign medals more than five years after the event. However, the Foreign Office made an exception and allowed the medals to be presented in 2013.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation found that offenders were not starting their unpaid work on time and were often let off if they did not attend. The report outlined 15 recommendations for improvement, including reducing the number of offenders turned away from work and creating objectives that match the offender's circumstances. The report also highlighted that many offenders viewed their sentence positively and were determined to desist from future offending. The Ministry of Justice said it was acting on the report's recommendations and wanted to make rehabilitation more effective.

Comedian Russell Brand has been accused of hypocrisy for campaigning for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home. Brand has defended himself by saying that he is aware of the accusations and that he is working to change his own life, but that systemic change is also necessary. He believes that the accusations of hypocrisy are a way to avoid addressing the real problem of inequality.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his groundbreaking work in human genomics and synthetic biology. He is a controversial figure, often criticized for his competitive approach and disregard for scientific conventions. Despite this, his work has significantly accelerated the field of genomics. He is credited with creating the first complete genome of a free-living organism and leading the effort to map the human genome. Dr. Venter's latest achievement is the creation of Synthia, a synthetic life form, which he believes has the potential to revolutionize industry and help address environmental issues.

A survey of 1,000 parents in England found that 80% of children who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school. Half of the parents surveyed said their children had requested school lunch foods at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were the least popular. The survey was conducted online between February 26th and March 5th.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, joined Juventus in 2014 after playing four seasons with Real Madrid.  Real Madrid had the option to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. Morata scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He also played in back-to-back Champions League finals, appearing as a substitute in Real's 2014 win and scoring in Juventus' 3-1 defeat by Barcelona in 2015.

Former Celtic and Nottingham Forest player, 30-year-old Dexter Wilson, is currently without a team after being released in May. He previously played for Nottingham Forest for four seasons before joining Celtic, and then returned to Nottingham Forest in 2013 for £2.5 million. Wilson has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles based private equity company. The deal will transfer around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees to the new business. Tesco will loan the new business around £80 million and will cost Tesco £150 million to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. Tesco has the option to buy a stake in the business if Yucaipa is successful and the business becomes profitable.

The passage describes an athlete who overcame racial abuse and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. He considered representing France but ultimately decided to compete for his current country.

A new study of the French Alps glaciers has found that the area covered by ice has decreased by 26% over the last 40 years. The study, conducted by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie, used map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs to assess the roughly 600 glaciers in the region. The greatest losses have been seen in the southern sectors, with glaciers in the Belledonne Massif almost completely disappearing. The retreat is less pronounced in the northern Alps, which includes the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace. The study mirrors findings from other parts of the Alps, which have also seen glaciers losing mass at an accelerating rate.

Scotland's women's national football team is on the verge of qualifying for the 2017 European Championship. They have won all five of their qualifying matches and are in a strong position to reach the finals in the Netherlands. The team is led by Bayern Munich forward Jane Evans, who is one of 12 players in the squad who play outside of Scotland. Evans believes that the experience of playing in top leagues abroad has helped the team improve and is confident that they can beat Iceland in their upcoming qualifying match.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence blogger, was arrested in the west of England on Friday after a woman in south London alleged he harassed her over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, claims the harassment involved tweets that were not threatening and accused the media of encouraging speculation. The Metropolitan Police are investigating the allegations of online harassment.

Peta is asking for the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness to be replaced with a fish mascot with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" because they believe the Jolly Fisherman represents animal cruelty. The mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, said he doesn't think there will be much support for the mascot to be replaced and that the Jolly Fisherman is loved by many.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, scoring six tries to two. Scotland dominated possession and territory in the first half, scoring three quick tries and holding Georgia to only one try. Georgia scored their second try in the second half, but Scotland responded with another try to secure the victory. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance, highlighting their ability to hold the ball and counter-attack effectively.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-24, moving them into 7th place in the league. Widnes had a 26-point lead before Castleford scored three tries in four minutes, making the final score closer.  Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a Kuwaiti citizen detained at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, was released after a US review panel determined he was not a threat to the US. He will now spend at least a year at a rehabilitation center in Kuwait. Mr. Odah was the first inmate released since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. His release brings the total number of inmates at Guantanamo Bay down to 148.

Anzac Day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The day is marked by services in London, including a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade to the Cenotaph, and a service at Westminster Abbey. The services honor the sacrifices of Australian and New Zealand soldiers in all wars. The first Anzac Day commemoration in London was in 1916 when King George V attended a service at Westminster Abbey.

St Mirren's new player, 30-year-old striker,  Jonathan Clarkson, is ready to make his debut against Alloa on Saturday. Clarkson has played for several teams including Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. He scored nine goals last season at Dundee and is looking forward to helping St Mirren move up the Championship table.

The Bernard Matthews turkey firm was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan.  Unite, the union representing the workers, was assured that the current pension arrangements would remain in place under the new ownership.  Boparan plans to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability by investing in the business, cutting costs, and utilizing the company's spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The new chain ferry in Cowes has had a difficult start, experiencing breakdowns, groundings, and training issues. The council has ordered an audit of the project and is offering free crossings until July 2nd to gather feedback. Local businesses are suffering from the loss of trade and are seeking compensation. The council is considering compensation and has authorized ramp extensions to address vehicle damage.

The House of Lords European Union Committee released a report that examines the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry after Brexit. The report warns that the UK may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a deal. The report also states that the UK fishing industry is small, accounting for only 0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 people. The report suggests that the UK should retain many elements of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and continue to base total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. The report also notes that the UK will continue to be under international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. Despite the report's warnings, many in the fishing industry remain optimistic about Brexit, believing it will bring more opportunities than threats.

Timothy Geaney, a former teacher, was found guilty of possessing child pornography and was removed from the General Teaching Council Scotland register. He was sentenced to a community payback order and required to participate in a sex offender program. The panel found that Geaney's actions were "fundamentally incompatible" with being a teacher and that there was a "strong likelihood of the offending behaviour recurring." He was prohibited from re-registering for two years.

On March 2nd, a fire at a waste facility in Duncan Street caused travel delays and service disruptions. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the facility's waste acceptance permit after determining that the site operators, Asset and Land Group, were "broadly compliant" with fire safety regulations.
