The protest was organized by fan groups from both clubs, who believe that the current ticket prices are "extortionate" and are driving away fans.

Star Reader, a newborn baby, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. Her parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were told she would need a liver transplant to survive. Neither parent was a suitable match, but Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered part of her liver and saved her niece's life. Star underwent the transplant in November and has since made a good recovery.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake teamed up to take on Loic Remy and Willian in a series of challenges for Audi. The challenges included shooting balls into the boot of a car, sinking balls into a convertible Audi from long range, and playing tennis over the top of an Audi R8 V10 Plus. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, but Remy and Willian won the final round, which involved shooting at cars from long range.  Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror off one of the Audis during the final challenge.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, was sentenced for causing a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus' death. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison. Dellinger claims he was not suicidal when he drove his truck across a median at over 100 mph, but prosecutors say he told investigators he was trying to kill himself. Dellinger's attorneys claim he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, the effects of a psychiatric drug overdose and prozac, and the advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears. Spears was found guilty of second-degree murder after she poisoned her son with salt while he was hospitalized. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and frustration on Facebook, stating that he hoped Spears would die in prison. Prosecutors argued that Spears poisoned her son for attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence. Spears' social media posts about her son's illnesses and hospitalizations were used as evidence against her.

Australia will receive a new influenza vaccine in April that will protect against two new strains of influenza, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter. The vaccine was modified after the previous version did not provide adequate protection against these strains. The new vaccine will be available for free to high-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and Indigenous Australians, starting April 20. Experts recommend that everyone get the vaccine, as it also provides protection against the H1N1 strain.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from a National Geographic article and budget cuts that threaten the site's management. The article criticizes the tomb's interior as lacking historical character, while the state of Illinois is considering eliminating the agency that manages the site. Despite these challenges, the tomb has undergone recent renovations and remains a popular tourist destination.

The article discusses nine fashion trends from the 1990s and early 2000s that are making a comeback. The trends include bucket hats, camouflage print, double denim, Ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. The article provides examples of celebrities who wore these trends in the past and who are wearing them again today.

This week's trending stories include: a photo of four rainbows in the sky after heavy rain in New York, China's crackdown on exotic dancers performing at wakes, Robert Downey Jr.'s frustration with a UK interviewer's questions about his private life, the "Kylie Jenner Challenge" of lip plumping by sucking on a jar, a 102-year-old woman's prom-posal, Ewan McGregor's casting as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's transformation for "Black Mass," and creative pregnancy and photobomb announcements.

Serena Williams won her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets to advance to the semi-finals.  Williams will face Simona Halep for a spot in the finals.  Andy Murray also celebrated his 500th career victory at the Miami Open.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and cafe owner, was shot and killed in Karachi after hosting a discussion on the disappearance of people in Baluchistan. Mahmud was known for her outspoken views on human rights and women's entrepreneurship, and her cafe was a popular gathering place for young Pakistanis seeking freedom of thought. She had received death threats in the past for her work, and her killing has sparked outrage and grief across the country.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer, fled to Kashmir as a refugee in 1947. He and thousands of other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) have been denied citizenship rights, including the right to own property or vote in state elections, for 70 years. This has resulted in three generations of WPRs living in abject poverty. The reluctance of successive state governments to grant full rights to the WPRs stems from fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. However, with the recent success of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in the state elections, there is hope that the WPRs will finally be granted citizenship rights. The BJP is expected to champion the refugees' cause, but if their hopes are dashed again, the community is prepared to take matters into their own hands.

Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a move to Chelsea this summer. Chelsea has made an offer for the 22-year-old, but Muto wants to join a club where he can play regularly and develop his skills. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho has acknowledged Muto's talent but has declined to comment further on the potential transfer.

England’s rugby team is being criticized for its policy of not selecting players who play overseas. The author argues that England should follow Australia’s lead and select its best players, regardless of where they play. The author cites examples of players who have improved their game by playing overseas, such as Jonny Wilkinson and Nick Abendanon. The author believes that England’s policy is misguided and that the team should select its best players in order to have the best chance of winning the World Cup.

Firechat is an app that allows users to chat with friends without needing a mobile signal or internet connection. It uses a feature called Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) that creates a wireless mesh network where phones connect to each other and pass messages between nodes. While this network has a limited range of 200 feet, Open Garden has developed a device called Greenstone that acts as a beacon to extend the range of the network. Greenstone is still under development but can currently extend the range of Firechat to 20 feet. It can hold up to 1,000 messages and has a one-year battery life.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, is working to change the negative connotations associated with the word "fat" by embracing it as a positive and honest description of her own body. She argues that the word "fat" should not be synonymous with "ugly" and that beauty comes in all shapes and sizes. Bustle believes that exposure to body diversity can lead to greater tolerance and acceptance of different body types. She uses her burlesque performances to showcase a "fat" body in a positive and glamorous way, challenging societal norms about what is considered desirable. Bustle's TED Talk has received overwhelmingly positive feedback, with many viewers expressing gratitude and sharing personal stories about how it has impacted their own body image.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been sitting on the bench for most of the season. He recently posed for a photoshoot with his Arsenal teammates for Lanvin, the club's official tailor since 2013. Walcott has been named on the substitutes' bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games this season. He came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's 0-0 draw with Chelsea on Sunday. Walcott hopes to make his first start since March 14th when Arsenal faces Hull on Monday.

A collection of props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker will be auctioned off on May 29th. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, includes items from over 50 productions, spanning Baker's 30-year career. Some of the items, such as the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black, are expected to fetch more than $40,000. The auction will be held at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on Propstore.com.

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old boy from Wales, died while skiing with his family in the French Alps. He became separated from his mother and went into dense woodland where he fell over a 164ft drop. His mother desperately searched for him, and footprints in the snow led police to his body. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined boy who loved skiing and snowboarding. His family said they had spent a happy ski holiday together before the tragedy occurred.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after being bullied for her weight and feeling pressured to be a size zero. She would hide food and eat only a piece of fruit a day, leading to her collapse and hospitalization. After spending a week on a heart monitor, Laura began working with eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services to recover. Today, she has a better body image and has made it to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive and confidence-building experiences for young girls, away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool supporters cheered Raheem Sterling on as he modeled the new Liverpool kit at Anfield. The new kit is the first offering from New Balance, who signed a record-breaking £300 million four-year kit deal to replace Warrior as Liverpool's suppliers. Sterling recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract offer from Liverpool, but the club is adamant that he will not be leaving this summer.

The University of Manchester has released the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and shows clumps of dark matter particles. The goal of the Dark Energy Survey (DES) is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy. The map is created by studying the distortion of light from distant galaxies caused by the gravitational pull of dark matter, a phenomenon known as gravitational lensing. The DES will help scientists better understand the formation of galaxies and the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be causing the expansion of the universe to speed up.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven. Louis van Gaal, the manager of Manchester United, is eager to sign Depay, who he previously coached on the Dutch national team. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season for PSV, and is considered a rising star in the sport.  Depay has been compared to Cristiano Ronaldo by Ed van Steijn, who scouted Ronaldo for Manchester United.  Depay has also been compared to Arjen Robben by his current manager, Phillip Cocu.

Chelsea defeated Manchester City's youth team 3-1 in the Youth Cup semi-final. Tammy Abraham scored twice in the first half, and Dominic Solanke added a third goal late in the game. Chelsea's defense was strong, with Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke-Salter combining well to nullify City's attack. City's best player was Brandon Barker, who created a number of chances for his team.

Marco Rubio, a Republican presidential candidate, believes that people are born with a sexual preference but that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right. He believes that states should decide whether or not to allow gay marriage and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. Rubio has said he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he did not agree with the decision.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who quit their jobs in Manchester to cycle around the world. They have no set plans or agenda, and they are living on less than three euros a day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping, couchsurfing, and warmshowers. They have been on the road for 356 days, covering almost 7,000 miles and visiting 16 countries. They started in London and have cycled through Europe, including France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey. They are currently in Armenia and plan to continue cycling through Asia, across the Pacific, and down the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple is suing a photo booth company, Premiere Photos, owned by James Evans, after discovering racist slurs printed on the bottom of their wedding photos. The couple, who wish to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to file a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The couple claims that Evans did not apologize for the incident and told them to "sue" him. Evans denies the allegations and claims there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. The couple is seeking an apology from Evans and is not motivated by financial gain. Mediation is scheduled for the following morning, and if no agreement is reached, the case will go to trial in July.

Mike Brown, an England fullback, is taking a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion. He pulled out of a recent game after experiencing a headache and feeling unwell. Brown is determined not to rush his recovery and is aware of the long-term dangers of concussion. He believes that increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by online modules, has helped him make the right decision to prioritize his health. Brown encourages other players to be honest about their symptoms and not risk further injury.

A leading expert, Professor David Spiegelhalter, suggests that the decline in sexual activity among couples in Britain may be due to increased smartphone use. He cites research that shows the frequency of sex has decreased since the emergence of the internet, with couples now having sex three times a month compared to five times a month in 1990. Professor Spiegelhalter attributes this decline to the blurring of boundaries between work and personal life, leading to less time for couples to spend together. He also notes that the increased demands on our time, such as dealing with work emails late at night, can make it difficult to focus on our partners.

The Tibetan Mastiff, once a status symbol in China, is now being sent to slaughterhouses due to a decline in popularity. The anti-corruption crackdown in China has made it less desirable to give the dogs as gifts, and recent bans on owning large dogs in several cities have also contributed to the decline. The breed's popularity peaked in 2005, with one puppy selling for £1.2 million. However, unscrupulous breeders have crossbred the dogs, resulting in a glut of poor-quality dogs that cannot be sold. Additionally, the dogs are not well-suited to city living, and many are being stolen from the streets and sold to slaughterhouses.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris area found that every woman surveyed had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transportation. Half of the women surveyed had experienced harassment before the age of 18. The survey found that women are often conditioned to accept low-level abuse, making them unaware of the extent of the problem. The survey led to calls for a campaign to stop sexist and threatening behavior on public transportation.

Direct Line, an insurance company, held a competition called #everydayfix to design products that solve common everyday problems.  The top ten problems identified were: not being able to sleep, losing keys, being stuck in traffic, losing important documents, nowhere to park, printer not working, running out of phone battery, running out of toilet paper, dealing with automated customer service, and forgetting your bank card.  Three products were chosen as finalists: Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure a good night's sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that fastens to a key and turns green when the door is open and red when it is locked; and Nipper, a small mobile phone charger that uses household batteries.  The winner of the competition, determined by the most retweets on Twitter with the #everydayfix hashtag, will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public money to a charity she directs, Victims First Northumbria. The charity also has Northumbria's Chief Constable Sue Sim on its board. Critics have called the situation a conflict of interest and an inappropriate use of public funds. The Ministry of Justice is investigating whether any conflict of interest rules were broken.

A group of people, dubbed the "tattoo terrorists," were convicted of assaulting and torturing a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, in Philadelphia. The ringleader, Corry "Corey" Campbell, believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and friend Carl Halin, beat, tied up, and tattooed Valecce over a period of 42 hours. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was able to escape and contact police. Campbell and Halin were sentenced to 20 years in prison, while Ng received a 23-month sentence. Two other individuals, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign Memphis Depay from PSV Eindhoven. Louis van Gaal, the manager of Manchester United, is eager to sign Depay, who he previously coached on the Dutch national team. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season for PSV, and is considered a rising star in the sport.  Depay has been compared to Cristiano Ronaldo by Ed van Steijn, who scouted Ronaldo for Manchester United.  Depay has also been compared to Arjen Robben by his current manager, Phillip Cocu.

Qatar Airways is based in Doha, Qatar and operates a hub-and-spoke network, connecting over 160 international destinations across the globe. The airline uses a fleet of over 200 aircraft and is headquartered in the Qatar Airways Tower.

Qatar Airways is headquartered in Doha and operates a hub-and-spoke network, connecting over 150 international destinations across the globe. The airline uses a fleet of over 200 aircraft and is based at Hamad International Airport.
Maxthon is a popular web browser, especially in China where it is the second most popular. It has been downloaded over 400 million times globally.

The novel coronavirus has infected more people worldwide than have been reported, resulting in over 16,700 deaths and over 102,000 recoveries.
As of the time of this data, there have been over 392,000 confirmed cases of the disease worldwide, resulting in over 17,100 deaths. Over 102,000 people have recovered.

Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but admitted he was wrong after Townsend scored a stunning goal for England against Italy. Merson continued to criticize Townsend after he was brought on for Tottenham in the 83rd minute of their 0-0 draw with Burnley.

Chelsea has made an offer to FC Tokyo for 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto. If he joins Chelsea this summer, he will be loaned to their Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem next season. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea. He has earned 11 caps for Japan and scored once for the Samurai Blue. A £4 million deal has been proposed, but Muto has not yet decided if he will join the Premier League title chasers.

A study of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds in Finland found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The study found that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by the age of two, and those who had taken antibiotics as babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The researchers believe that antibiotics may be killing off gut bacteria that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study also found that repeated antibiotic prescriptions before the age of two increased the odds of being overweight. The researchers warn that the overuse of antibiotics could be contributing to the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell. The guard, wearing full regalia, fell to the ground, dropping his rifle. He quickly got up, appearing embarrassed. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E, Lifetime, and History will simulcast a remake of the miniseries "Roots" in 2016. The new version will draw more from Alex Haley's novel and will be more "original" and "contemporary." LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new miniseries. The remake will be more authentic, consulting scholars in African and African-American history. The new "Roots" will encounter a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama's presidency and the Oscar win of "12 Years a Slave," but also widespread racial unrest.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, claims that he was sexually assaulted by Clarence House aides in 1978. Lawler claims that he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff on his first day working at Clarence House. He reported the incident to the palace, but his complaint was ignored for months. After hearing about the probe into historical cases of child abuse last year, Lawler wrote to the Palace, but was twice rebuffed. Months later the complaint was finally passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide, who is now in his 80s, was reportedly interviewed but denied he was involved because he was working for the Queen in Balmoral at the time. The Palace has stated that they will work "exhaustively and co-operatively" with any police probe.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from the 90s sitcom "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air." The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. The video was made to share the news with loved ones living far away. The couple was surprised by the video's popularity, which they say has been a lot of fun.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh in the film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at auction. The dress, a jacket and skirt ensemble, was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett O'Hara encounters Rhett Butler. The dress was part of a collection of over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia amassed by James Tumblin, who worked in the hair and makeup department at Universal Studios. Tumblin purchased the dress for $20 from the Western Costume Company. Other items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh that sold for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler that sold for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland that fetched $30,000.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the edge. The boy was rescued by his parents before emergency personnel arrived. He suffered minor injuries and is in stable condition. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

A speed camera in Birmingham, West Midlands, has been turned to face a residential house. The camera has been out of service for two years, as all fixed cameras in the region were decommissioned in 2013 due to outdated technology. The city council is aware of the re-pointed camera and will be sending an engineer to assess the situation. The camera will not be included in a new pilot program using digital technology.

Usain Bolt will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team. Bolt is excited to be part of the team and is fit and ready to run. He is looking forward to the competition and hopes to make Jamaica proud. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates on the Barcelona football team, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending the El Clasico match against Real Madrid. Barcelona won the match 85-80, but Real Madrid remains in first place in their division. Neymar also played for Brazil in a 1-0 win over Chile, where he was the subject of several rough tackles. Barcelona is currently in first place in La Liga and will play Celta Vigo on Sunday.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. The Italian Coast Guard rescued 8,480 migrants from Friday to Monday, and received 20 SOS calls on Monday alone. Save the Children reported that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized off the Libyan coast, but the Coast Guard has not confirmed this incident. The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reported that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with 2,000 rescued at sea in early April. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather, overcrowded vessels, and abandonment by smugglers.

Alexis Sanchez, a Chilean forward, chose to play for Arsenal over Liverpool. Sanchez was courted by many clubs after Barcelona decided to let him go. Wenger, Arsenal's manager, believes Liverpool's interest in Sanchez may have been a tactic to gain leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Sanchez has made an immediate impact on English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger is impressed with Sanchez's quick adaptation to a new environment and believes he is one of the best players around. Wenger also commented on Liverpool's manager, Brendan Rodgers, saying he has done well in developing the team despite the loss of Suarez and the injury to Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7th at the Lee Valley Velodrome in London. Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins will be racing in front of a sell-out crowd at the Olympic Velodrome. Tickets for the event will go on sale on April 19th.

Serena Williams won her singles match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, but the US team lost the match 3-2, relegating them to World Group II. Williams was not happy with her performance, saying she was not ready for the claycourt season and needs to adjust her game. The US team will need to work harder to get back to the World Group next year.

River Plate is interested in signing former striker Radamel Falcao, who has struggled at Manchester United. The Argentine club's vice president, Matias Patanian, said that they "dream of Falcao" and that "the doors are open." Falcao played for River Plate from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances.

Ella Henderson, a pop star who rose to fame on The X Factor, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste for their 2015 "Ready For It" campaign. This is Henderson's first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, including a wavy style and a half-ponytail, against a blurred city background. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV ad featuring Henderson's song "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the collaboration, as she is a regular user of Batiste products.

A billboard featuring the officer who shot and killed Aaron Siler was erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanked the community for its support. Siler's family and friends are calling for the billboard to be taken down, saying it is disrespectful. The police association claims no offense was intended and that the billboard was simply to thank the community for its support. The officer, Pablo Torres, is currently on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into the shooting.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in a clash with militants near the Pakistan border. The militants, who crossed into Iran from Pakistan, were from the group Jaish al Adal, which claimed responsibility for the attack. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian group that has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan. The Pakistani government condemned the attack and is investigating the incident.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told the Diet that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object. He said that when the ASDF detects indications of an unidentified flying object that could violate Japan's airspace, it scrambles fighter jets if necessary and makes visual observation. Nakatani said that they sometimes find birds or flying objects other than aircraft but he doesn't know of a case of finding an unidentified flying object believed to have come over from anywhere other than Earth. This response was given to a query from flamboyant former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who claims to have seen a UFO with his own eyes, but admitted that he didn't know personally if aliens existed.

A 35-year-old passenger in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, China, was hospitalized after breaking a toilet he was squatting on. The man, Jin Pai, was standing on the rim of the toilet because he was worried about its cleanliness. The toilet collapsed, causing deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He was found bleeding on the floor and was taken to the hospital where he received stitches. Police believe the incident was an accident and reminded people that toilets are for sitting on, not standing on.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, was arrested for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The girl discovered the camera in March and told investigators that Rebbie had been watching her for years while she was undressing and sleeping. Rebbie faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. He is being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of photos featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The photos, which are part of a book titled "Daughter and Salary Man," show the fathers in sharp suits, while the daughters are casually dressed. The photos are gaining attention online for their unique and humorous nature.

Kevin Pietersen, who was controversially axed from the England team in 2014, is hoping to make a comeback to the international set-up. He has rejoined Surrey and is looking to force his way back into the Test team. Pietersen was in a jovial mood at the Surrey team photo shoot, but also appeared to be in deep thought as he reflected on his potential return to the England team.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club, fired their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Ze Maria was initially fired on Wednesday due to poor performance, but was reinstated the next day. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday, he was fired again. Ze Maria, a former Brazilian international, was replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao is regretting his move to Manchester United. Falcao has struggled to perform at Manchester United and has only scored four goals this season. Dirar believes Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he was unhappy but would have played in the Champions League.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask robbed a dairy in Christchurch, New Zealand. The robber, described as being very tall, was wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and demanded cash from the owner's daughter. He took the till drawer and approximately $1,500 in cash before fleeing the scene. Police are asking for the public's help in identifying the suspect.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for a second time on charges of having sex with a 15-year-old student. The alleged sexual encounters took place on two consecutive nights in January in Granado's car. This arrest comes after Granado was previously arrested in March for having an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student, which involved kissing and allowing the student to touch her breasts. Granado was released on bail both times.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its mouth has gone viral. The crocodile, which was seen calmly moving through the marina, held onto the dog for hours. The dog, belonging to the local bike shop owner, went to the water's edge to see the crocodile and was attacked. The crocodile is believed to have come from a nearby sanctuary. Social media users have reacted with horror to the video, with some expressing hatred for crocodiles. However, crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, as the resort is built amongst mangroves that the creatures have called home for centuries.

Hull City lost to Southampton 2-0, leaving them two points above the relegation zone. Despite a strong start to the season, Hull has only won six games and is now facing a difficult schedule with games against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Manager Steve Bruce is confident that Hull can stay in the Premier League, citing their recent success and the return of key players from injury. Bruce attributes Hull's struggles to long-term injuries to key players, including Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton moved up to fifth in the table after their win, but manager Ronald Koeman had to address Sadio Mane's attempt to take a penalty despite James Ward-Prowse being the designated penalty taker.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewskesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he allowed pupils to change their answers on their SATs exams. The Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school after an investigation found that some pupils had changed answers outside exam conditions and that Guffick had also altered some of the pupils' exam answers himself. Guffick admitted to the allegations and accepted that his actions amounted to unacceptable professional conduct. Although he claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible, the panel found that no changes of any kind should be made to exam scripts outside test conditions.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, is enjoying his time off the pitch with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri. The couple married in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year and have a son together. Lindegaard has struggled to find playing time at Manchester United and is currently third-choice goalkeeper. He has been told he can leave the club and was linked with a move to FC Midtjylland in January, but the two clubs could not agree on a price.

The 13 blue letters that once lit up Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction. The letters, which were expected to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, received no bids except for a starting bid of $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. The letters were purchased by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson in 2008 after the stadium's final game. Jackson hoped to sell the letters to a new generation, but they failed to attract any bids.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed the recent controversy surrounding Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were photographed using nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to the players about their professional responsibilities and the importance of their actions, but he will not be disciplining them. He emphasized that while some actions may seem normal to young people, they can be perceived differently in the public eye. Rodgers is focused on leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final and is not revealing whether he will immediately recall Steven Gerrard, who is available after a three-match suspension. Rodgers believes that the team's near misses in the title race and Capital One Cup are part of their journey and will help them improve in the future.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's German playmaker, returned to London after playing in a Euro 2016 qualifier for Germany. He is expected to start in Arsenal's upcoming match against Liverpool. Ozil has been in good form since returning from injury, scoring three goals and assisting on four others. He has adjusted to English football, enjoying the frequent matches and lack of a winter break.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club has no plans to replace manager Luis Enrique, who has a contract until 2016. Bartomeu is very happy with Enrique's performance and says he is impressed with how the manager has performed since taking charge last summer.  Enrique is only six games away from winning the La Liga title.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club. The new deal will run until 2020 and is worth around £100,000 a week. Henderson, who joined Liverpool in 2011, has been one of the most improved players under manager Brendan Rodgers. He is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy this summer.

Filipe Luis, a Chelsea fullback, has stated that he wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in bringing him back. Luis has struggled to secure the left back position at Chelsea since joining last July. Luis played for Brazil during the international break, but is now focused on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is demanding that his team stay focused and win every game. Luis acknowledges that the remaining nine games will be difficult, but believes Chelsea is prepared for the challenge.

Nathan Hughes, a rugby player for Wasps, was initially banned for three matches after a disciplinary panel ruled he had been reckless for accidentally knocking out George North, a player for Northampton. Hughes was shown a red card for the offense, but that dismissal has now been officially rescinded. The ban was overturned on appeal, with the appeal panel concluding that no act of foul play took place and that the incident occurred accidentally.

Wildfires in Siberia caused by farmers burning grass in their fields spread due to strong winds, destroying villages and creating a large amount of smoke. The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, causing intense red sunsets in Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filter out shorter wavelengths of light, leaving red and orange colors to penetrate the air. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig's brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway. After being located by a man who recognized the car, it was returned to her with red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Schoenig was amused by the changes and posted a photo of her car on Facebook, writing that the thieves had "pimped out" her vehicle. While she was happy to have her car back, she is having it professionally cleaned to remove the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. She is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who located her car.

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The players have incentivised contracts to stay within financial fairplay requirements. City are currently in fourth place and will be just four points ahead of Liverpool if Liverpool beats Newcastle United on Monday. The top three finishers in the Premier League qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. City has lost seven times since the start of 2015, including early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a "mini-derby" match. The match was played at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium, which has a capacity of 6,000. The match was notable for its high level of skill and commitment, with both teams showcasing talented young players. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal for United with a free kick, while Marcus Rashford had two chances for City. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series.

Joe Hart, who earned his 50th cap for England, praised Gianluigi Buffon, who earned his 147th cap for Italy, calling him a "legend of the game." Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, said he looks up to Buffon and is inspired by him. Hart is proud of his 50 caps and wants to continue playing for England.

Chipotle Mexican Grill has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery services in 67 cities. The delivery service will cost a 9% service charge, plus a delivery fee starting at $5. Chipotle is not the only restaurant chain to offer delivery services. Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also offering or planning to offer delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, are asking the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the man convicted of the crime. They argue that the death penalty would prolong the legal process and force them to relive the painful events of that day. The Richards believe that Tsarnaev should spend the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release. They want to move on from the tragedy and focus on the future.

A mystery billionaire has spent £400 million customizing a Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet to be his personal luxury home. The plane, which would normally carry 600 passengers, has been transformed to accommodate a single tycoon and dozens of guests. It features a dining room with an adjoining kitchen, a lounge, a state room, an aeroloft with eight beds, a master bedroom, a conference room, and a guest bedroom/office. The plane's interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel, with plush furnishings, a large television, and a hotel-like ambience.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station. The rocket landed on a floating barge, but tipped over. SpaceX hopes to reuse rockets to reduce the cost of space travel. The Dragon will deliver supplies to the space station and return with science experiments and trash. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station.

Priscilla Presley will be a witness at the first wedding to be held at the Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas on April 23rd. The winning couple will be announced next Monday and will receive a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite, airfare, and concert tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside of his Memphis home.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a tough season. Henderson and Liverpool goalkeeper Simon Mignolet both played their 47th game of the season in the 2-0 win over Newcastle United on Monday night. Henderson believes that after finding winning form again, Liverpool can put pressure on City, who are four points ahead in the race for the Champions League. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal in the ninth minute at Anfield, followed by Joe Allen's first Anfield goal in the 70th minute. Allen admitted that he thought Newcastle should have been awarded a penalty when Dejan Lovren appeared to foul Ayoze Perez in the area.

Roma defeated Napoli in a key Serie A match on Saturday, ending their four-month winless streak at home. Miralem Pjanic scored the only goal in the 25th minute, finishing off a swift counter-attack. Roma goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves in the second half to preserve the victory. The win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches. Security was tight for the match due to a fan death following a shooting before last season's Italian Cup final.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played a 0-0 draw at the Keepmoat Stadium. The match was uneventful, leaving the Doncaster media team with little to show in their match highlights video. They created a 27-second video with only 14 seconds of match action, showing the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish bred in Taiwan. He hand-feeds and massages his fish daily, which has become increasingly social and enjoys the interaction. The fish even swims up Giroux's arm and rests in his hand, seemingly enjoying the attention. Giroux believes the fish became more sociable after he removed two other fish that were bullying it.

Ben Stokes is a fiery character on the England cricket team who has a history of aggressive behavior, including punching a locker after being dismissed. While his aggression can be beneficial to the team, it needs to be controlled. England's coach, Peter Moores, has been working with Stokes to help him channel his aggression in a positive way. Stokes is a valuable asset to the team and England wants to help him reach his full potential.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium has sold out, with 33,000 tickets purchased. The match will be held at the Cardiff City Stadium on June 12th. Wales is currently in a strong position to qualify for the tournament, sitting in second place in Group B with 11 points. The team's recent 3-0 victory over Israel has increased expectations for qualification. The Football Association of Wales has been overwhelmed with ticket requests, leading to the sell-out. The team prefers to play at the Cardiff City Stadium, despite the larger capacity of the Millennium Stadium, due to UEFA rules preventing venue changes within 120 days of the match.

England's Under-17 team, the defending champions, will compete in the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria next month. The team, which qualified with a perfect record, is placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Their first match is against Italy on May 7th. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, including Chelsea, Arsenal, and Liverpool. Notable additions to the team include Arsenal's Chris Willock, who is making his first appearance, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who were absent during the Elite Round of qualifiers.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht player Evangelos Patoulidis. Patoulidis is considered one of the best young players in Anderlecht's youth program and has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously rejected a move to Barcelona's academy when he was 12, but has continued to impress. City has spoken with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock about a potential transfer.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, was found strangled and beaten to death in her Fulham flat in late March. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and has been bailed pending further questioning. Police are appealing to anyone who may have had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death.

Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show to confront her friend Jamie, who stole money she had saved for a headstone for her son Daniel James. Dawn had saved £207 for the headstone, but it went missing. She suspected Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, and a lie detector test revealed that Jamie had taken the money. Jamie confessed to taking the money in a Facebook message to Dawn, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal and left the show in tears.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, as well as the ill and elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders and the freed Yazidis were taken to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. This is not the first time ISIS has released Yazidis, as they have previously released scores of children and elderly. ISIS has been responsible for the displacement of hundreds of thousands of minorities, including Yazidis, from their homes. The Yazidis are a Kurdish group whose religion is considered a pre-Islamic sect that draws from Christianity, Judaism, and Zoroastrianism. They have long suffered persecution and ISIS's cruelty towards them has been extraordinary.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham Hotspur striker, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. The video, produced by Copa90, uses still photographs of Kane to create an animated effect, featuring some of his best goals and celebrations from the season. The video is entitled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?' and has been released ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday, where Kane is up against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez for the top prize.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers is the right man to lead Liverpool forward despite a season without trophies and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher believes that Rodgers should not be judged solely on one season and that the team needs time to gel. He also believes that the team needs to improve in certain areas and that the right signings will make a big difference. Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, where he has provided coaching in eight schools in deprived areas through his 23 Foundation.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport because security officers deemed it a security risk. His father, Phil, criticized the security staff for being "over-zealous" and said that the situation was "ludicrous." East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience but defended their decision, stating that the safety and security of passengers is their top priority and that all security regulations are set by the government.

A 31-year-old man named Rich, living in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend/wife. Rich described himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, and financially successful. He outlined a list of requirements for his ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit and attractive, good with her hands, a good cook, and great in bed. He also stated that he is willing to provide a gym membership, phone, and other benefits to the successful applicant.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is pushing for radical changes to increase the number of homegrown players in Premier League squads from eight to twelve.  Five former England managers, including Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, have written a letter to Dyke in support of his proposals. They argue that the English game will suffer if these changes are not implemented, as the pool of English talent playing at the top level is shrinking. The managers believe that England can still produce top young talent, but they need more opportunities to play.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby girl in the next episode of Poldark. Fans have commented on the show's fast-paced pregnancies, as Demelza goes from announcing her pregnancy to giving birth in a matter of minutes. This is reminiscent of the previous season, where Elizabeth, another character, also gave birth in a short amount of time.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own games and not worry about their relegation rivals. Despite a recent mini-revival, Pearson wants his team to remain focused on their own jobs and not get caught up in the predictions and form tables. He believes that Leicester's future is in their own hands and that they have a realistic chance of survival if they focus on their own games.

A gray whale named Varvara swam nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, breaking the record for the longest mammal migration. This journey was surprising because Varvara visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale, not a western gray whale as previously thought. This discovery could mean that the number of western gray whales, which are endangered, is even lower than previously believed.

A landslide on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan, caused a section of seabed to rise as high as 50ft above sea level. The new stretch of coastline is roughly 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Local residents were surprised by the sudden appearance of the landmass, as they did not hear any sounds or feel any tremors. Geologists believe the landslide was caused by melting ice and snow, which caused a section of land to drop, pivoting the underwater area into the air. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further and believe it is unrelated to the recent earthquake in Nepal.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors that he will leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer. He says he is happy in Paris and wants to sign a new contract. He recently had a disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped from the Champions League match against Chelsea. However, he says he is ready to play whenever called upon. PSG is rumored to be interested in Barcelona star Dani Alves, which could lead to Van der Wiel being sold.

Carlos Tevez has requested to terminate his contract with Juventus to return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina. Juventus is reluctant to lose their top scorer, but they have accepted his request and are looking for a replacement. Boca Juniors is close to completing a deal for Tevez, but he must terminate his contract with Juventus first. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, has stated that Tevez's decision will not affect his future with the Argentina national team.

Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1 in the Champions League quarter-final, advancing to the semi-finals. Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped a hole in his trousers during the match, revealing his underwear. Bayern Munich's victory was a dominant performance, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, resulting in ten people injured, including four children. Two adults and two children were airlifted to the Princess Alexandra Hospital, while six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital. The highway was closed for several hours while emergency crews worked to free a trapped person and clear the scene.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch and shared his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from the show Knight Rider. Ozil is expected to start for Arsenal in their upcoming match against Chelsea. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six games remaining, but has been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere. Former Arsenal player Ray Parlour believes that Wilshere has the potential to be a key player for the club, but his fitness is a concern.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby between Manchester United and Manchester City at Old Trafford. Clattenburg has sent off three players from both teams this season, including City captain Vincent Kompany, who is suspended for the match against Wales in June. Despite accusations of favoring Manchester United, Clattenburg has only sent off two players in the Premier League this season, both from United. The derby is significant as it could determine who finishes second in the league, with Manchester United currently leading Manchester City by one point.

Bob Katter, a federal MP from Queensland, Australia, has been accused of racism after he stated that the Queensland Government assumed embattled MP Billy Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, said he has experienced racism from both major parties and believes the government treated Gordon as a "black puppet on a string." Katter's statement has been met with criticism on social media, with many users questioning his terminology. Katter has defended his statement, saying he used the term "black puppet" because he has experienced similar racist attitudes due to his own ethnicity.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy. She has created videos of herself dancing to challenge stereotypes about people with disabilities. Dobias says she wants to inspire others and show that people with disabilities are just like everyone else. She has also begun motivational speaking at local schools.

Javier Hernandez, a Manchester United player, is being pursued by Orlando City, an MLS team with a large Latin-American fanbase. Hernandez has had a difficult time on loan at Real Madrid and is also being considered by eight European teams. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to Andreas Pereira, a 19-year-old prospect who has also attracted interest from several European clubs.

Early Saturday morning, a group of three or more people attempted to carjack a man pumping gas at a 76 gas station in South Los Angeles. When the man ran away, the group poured gasoline on his car and set it on fire. The driver and two passengers escaped unharmed, but the car was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor in Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his license after admitting to trading sexual favors for services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite these actions, Manuel received positive patient satisfaction reviews on HealthGrades.com. He is prohibited from practicing chiropractic in Iowa for at least 10 years, but can apply for reinstatement after that time if he can prove the circumstances surrounding the revocation of his license no longer exist.

The United States is complaining to Russia about a Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepting a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea. The Pentagon claims the Russian pilot's actions were "unsafe and unprofessional" due to aggressive maneuvers in close proximity to the U.S. aircraft. Russia claims the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder switched off, but the U.S. denies this. This is not the first time the U.S. has complained about an incident involving a RC-135U and an SU-27.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City. The rifle was secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains, but the thief broke the car window, tied a rope around the case, and used another vehicle to pull the case free. The theft occurred just a week before President Obama's visit to Utah, and the Secret Service was notified. The agent's other belongings were found at a nearby hotel, but the rifle has not been recovered. Police are investigating the incident and have entered the rifle's serial number into the National Crime Information Computer.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his neighbor Terrence Freebody in July 2012. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen believes Costa was suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time of the murder. Professor Mullen stated that Costa's fluctuating mood and the trail of feces found at the crime scene suggest a confused mental state. The prosecution believes Costa was feigning memory loss during his interview with Professor Mullen. Costa's state of mind is critical to the case, as the jury can return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton won their match against Burnley 1-0, but not without a penalty controversy. Ross Barkley took the penalty, despite Leighton Baines being on the pitch, and missed. Baines has a strong record of scoring penalties, but manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, saying that he is happy to have multiple players who can take penalties. Barkley's miss did not prove costly, as Mirallas scored the winning goal later in the game.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The cruise line, Holland America, is cooperating with the FBI in their investigation, which is currently underway. The ship departed from Tampa, Florida on March 29th and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to the second round of CONCACAF World Cup qualifying for the 2018 tournament. Curacao drew 2-2 in the second leg against Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan player, has won many trophies in his career, but he says that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be just as rewarding. Leicester is currently in last place and needs to win several games to avoid relegation. Cambiasso is confident that Leicester can stay in the Premier League and says that he is happy in the East Midlands and could stay beyond his current one-year-deal.

Gemma, a 23-year-old mother of two, is at risk of being banned from seeing her children by her mother, Debbie, because of her partying and drinking habits. Gemma gave her two children to Debbie when they were four months old, and Debbie has been raising them ever since. Debbie claims that Gemma is constantly drinking and partying, and that she stole an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle. Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past, but denies stealing the iPad. Debbie is now threatening to ban Gemma from seeing the children because she doesn't trust her.

During a Chelsea vs. Manchester United match, Chelsea defender John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, which led to a loose ball that Chelsea used to score a goal. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness all agreed that Terry's challenge was a foul, despite the fact that Falcao could have stayed on his feet.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway Thursday morning. Everyone on board was safely evacuated after a rear tire blew out. The fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except Scott's Bible. The band is set to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday in Arlington, Texas.

A Scottish scientist is working on a laser that will convert sunlight into energy. The satellites will orbit the earth, covered in mirrors to help it harvest the sunlight and convert it into laser light. The energy it then creates, using semi-conductors, can be shot back down to earth. If it works, it could mean solar power could even become viable in Scotland, or be able to restore power instantly to disaster hit areas.  The scientist has acknowledged that there may be concerns about who controls the satellites.

Stephen Munden, a convicted paedophile with a history of child sexual abuse, has escaped from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act after sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus, was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday evening. Police are urging anyone with information about his whereabouts to contact them immediately.

V. Stiviano was ordered to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts she received from Donald Sterling after his wife, Shelly Sterling, sued her. Shelly Sterling claimed that Stiviano targeted wealthy older men and that Donald Sterling used their money to buy Stiviano expensive gifts, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with the gifts and that she never took advantage of Donald Sterling.

Thierry Henry believes Arsenal needs to sign four top players in the summer to win the Premier League title. He believes they need a goalkeeper, center back, defensive midfielder, and striker. Henry specifically criticized Olivier Giroud, stating that Arsenal will struggle to win the league with him as their main striker. He used Chelsea as an example, stating that they were able to win the league after signing Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa.

Maurice Van Ryn, the CEO of Bega Cheese, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offenses, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. One of his victims, who cannot be named, told the court that she is scared for her future relationships and didn't understand why she was targeted. She said she didn't know the abuse was wrong when it happened and only spoke up after she heard he had been caught. She has since attempted suicide and is worried about the impact the abuse will have on her future relationships.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old midfielder for Arsenal, is recovering from a serious knee injury that sidelined him for over a year. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under 21s, marking his return to the field. Gnabry is feeling "better and better" and is looking forward to his next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70 feet down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales. Phillips had been out drinking with friends in Cardiff and ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. He ran into the dark and fell down the cliff, which was at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, said he would not have left Phillips if he had known the danger he was in. The coroner, Andrew Barkley, ruled the death an accident, stating that Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the danger posed by the cliff.

Despite a £42 million profit and bonuses for managers, the Passport Office has only compensated 2,191 people for the passport delays last summer.  The total amount paid out was £203,066, with an average of £92.68 per person.  Ministers refused to give a blanket refund to those who missed trips or had to pay extra for expedited services, citing the potential for setting a precedent.  The Passport Office could not say how many claims were rejected due to a system failure in their customer complaint database.

A semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, built in the 1930s, is up for auction. The house has remained largely untouched since its construction and features original details such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and vintage food items. The home also boasts an original bathroom and kitchen, wood-paneled hallway, and vintage cupboards. While some features have been upgraded, such as double-glazed windows, the auctioneers believe the cost of renovations could deter developers. The house is expected to sell for between £200,000 and £250,000.

Colin Kaepernick became the starting quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion. He led the team to the Super Bowl in 2013, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and lived there for a portion of her early life before moving to Texas and later San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45 mile freeway in New Jersey that connects the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through its NBCUniversal division, NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, a British musician, formed the band Blur with Graham Coxon after meeting at Stanway School. Blur's debut album, *Leisure*, was released in 1991. The band's self-titled album, released in 2001, achieved worldwide success. Albarn's debut solo album, *Everyday Robots*, was released in 2014 and featured collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia. As the capital, Mogadishu is home to many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by Nine Inch Nails, featured on their 1992 EP, *Broken*.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter who was born on August 14, 1964. He has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film *Shooter* follows a former Force Recon veteran, Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The TV series *Shooter* features Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action to stop a plot to assassinate the president.
"House" (also known as "House, M.D.") is an American medical drama television series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate. He was also convicted of the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After Manson was charged with these crimes, recordings of his songs were released commercially.

Sean Penn is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career in television and made his film debut in the drama *Taps* (1981). Penn gained critical acclaim for his roles in the crime dramas *At Close Range* (1986), *State of Grace* (1990), and *Carlito's Way* (1993). He became a prominent leading actor with the drama *Dead Man Walking* (1995), which earned him his first Academy Award nomination. Penn has received two more Oscar nominations for *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001), and won his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for *Mystic River* and a second one in 2008 for *Milk*.

Sir Donald Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer widely considered the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he continued to be involved in the sport as an administrator, selector, and writer for 30 years.

L.A. Reid has held several high-ranking positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He began his career with the band Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he is a member of Prophets of Rage.

The Millers was a multi-camera sitcom that aired on CBS for two seasons, from October 3, 2013 to July 18, 2015. The show was canceled by CBS on November 14, 2014, after only four episodes of its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards was the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995. She was a Democrat who gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas when she delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. Richards was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and her one-liners.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" independently in 2011.
"Boardwalk" is a 1979 American drama film written and directed by Stephen Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, starred in the film.
Simón Bolívar, also known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who led the fight for independence from Spain for Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama.
The Bermuda Triangle is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where many ships and aircraft have reportedly vanished under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick became the starting quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers in 2012 after Alex Smith suffered a concussion. He led the team to the Super Bowl in 2013, losing to the Baltimore Ravens. In 2013, his first full season as a starter, Kaepernick led the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a non-personal form of marketing communication that uses audio or visual messages to promote products, services, or ideas. It is distinct from personal selling because it is not directed at a specific individual. Advertising is delivered through various mass media, including traditional media like newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as newer media like search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
"Private Lives" is a 1930 play by Noël Coward and a 1931 film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957 to October 19, 1963.

Aristotle, a Greek philosopher and scientist, was born in Stagira, Greece. He studied at Plato's Academy in Athens from the age of 17 to 37. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon.

David Packouz is an American entrepreneur who was formerly an arms dealer. He is also a musician, inventor, and the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company. Packouz invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine.

Magic Johnson was a point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons. He won five NBA championships with the Lakers, including one in his rookie season. He retired for four years before returning to play 32 games for the Lakers in 1996. Johnson is a successful businessman and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is a comedy rock duo from Los Angeles, California, formed in 1994 by Jack Black and Kyle Gass. The band has released three albums and gained popularity after starring in their own television series in 1997.

James VI and I, King of Scotland, England, and Ireland, ruled from 1567 to 1625. He advocated for a single parliament for England and Scotland, achieving most of his goals in Scotland but facing many difficulties in England, including the Gunpowder Plot and conflicts with Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming 18th season of the British reality television series Big Brother. The show is hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, who has narrated the show since its inception in 2000. Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist known for his distinctive Geordie accent.

Saxony is a landlocked state in Germany, bordering other German states as well as Poland and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest state in Germany by area and the sixth most populous, with a population of 4 million. The history of Saxony spans over a millennium, and it is known for its wine region, which is one of the northernmost in Europe.
East End Park was a major league baseball stadium in Cincinnati, Ohio. The song "In the End" was written by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown began her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra" (Pawn) is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai and starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. The film was released on July 1, 1994, and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. It received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Originally, Divya Bharti was cast as the female lead and filmed many scenes, but after her death, Raveena Tandon replaced her. The film is also known for its popular songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is featured on singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is best known for writing the 1987 action film *Lethal Weapon* and directing the 2005 film *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang*.
"A View to a Kill" (1985) is the 14th James Bond film and the last to feature Roger Moore as the secret agent.
Papua is the largest and easternmost province of Indonesia, encompassing most of western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya and included all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though some rumors suggested his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez began her music career in 1999 with her debut album, "On the 6." In 2001, she became the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week with the release of her second album, "J.Lo," and the film, "The Wedding Planner." After a high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck, Lopez released her third album, "This Is Me... Then," in 2002. Following her marriage to Marc Anthony, she starred in the box office hit, "Shall We Dance?" In 2008, Lopez gave birth to twins and returned to prominence in 2011 with her role as a judge on "American Idol" and the release of her most commercially successful single, "On the Floor."

Working animals are domesticated animals trained to perform tasks for humans. These animals can be close companions, like guide dogs, or used for labor, like draft horses. They can also be trained for milking or herding, requiring human training to encourage cooperation. While wild animals can be tamed and trained, they are often used for entertainment due to their lack of trustworthiness and mild temper, unlike domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen.
